commit_message:
Move _make_instance_list call outside of DB transaction context

The _make_instance_list method is used to make an InstanceList object
out of database dict-like instance objects. It's possible while making
the list that the various _from_db_object methods that are called might
do their own database writes.

Currently, we're calling _make_instance_list nested inside of a 'reader'
database transaction context and we hit the error:

  TypeError: Can't upgrade a READER transaction to a WRITER
  mid-transaction

during the _make_instance_list call if anything tries to do a database
write. The scenario encountered was after an upgrade to Pike, older
service records without UUIDs were attempted to be updated with UUIDs
upon access, and that access happened to be during an instance list,
so it failed when trying to write the service UUID while nested inside
the 'reader' database transaction context.

This simply moves the _make_instance_list method call out from the
@db.select_db_reader_mode decorated _get_by_filters_impl method to the
get_by_filters method to remove the nesting.

Closes-Bug: #1746509

Change-Id: Ifadf408802cc15eb9769d2dc1fc920426bb7fc20

With Queen the deprecation cycle for neutron lbaas started
so default to a stand alone Octavia installation.

commit_message:
Alias zuul git repos to git.zuul-ci.org

This adds support for the cgit-alias directive added in
https://review.openstack.org/555105.  It's safe to land this change
before or after the implementation.

It also aliases the zuul project repos to git.zuul-ci.org.

Change-Id: I05a7156e092faad1457973b88537ec73012a5c96

[{'created': '2018-03-21 15:05:48.000000000', 'message': 'Fix vhd image conversion regression

A recent change introduced a regression: due to a wrong assignment,
we're no longer passing qemu-img the right format when converting
images to "vhd". Note that it expects the legacy "vpc" name.

This change addresses this issue.

Closes-Bug: #1757244

Change-Id: If7a2e3470403b45eff69dcf69b67615bb982a4eb
(cherry picked from commit cf9ea3fdb380e695aa2584106ee0c5b465b3055e)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix vhd image conversion regression

A recent change introduced a regression: due to a wrong assignment,
we're no longer passing qemu-img the right format when converting
images to "vhd". Note that it expects the legacy "vpc" name.

This change addresses this issue.

Closes-Bug: #1757244

Change-Id: If7a2e3470403b45eff69dcf69b67615bb982a4eb
(cherry picked from commit cf9ea3fdb380e695aa2584106ee0c5b465b3055e)

commit_message:
Adding support to extend attached ScaleIO volumes

Implementing necessary mathods and rescaning storage
as necessary to support extending ScaleIO volumes
which are currently attached.

Change-Id: Icb9fc4fe1c16c34d8de9287046045d0837b7e80e

commit_message:
Windows iSCSI: ensure disks are claimed by MPIO

This change ensures that the retrieved disks are claimed by the
MPIO service, when multipath is requested.

At the same time, we're attempting to retrieve the disks only after
connecting all the requested targets.

Change-Id: I5e9e01d42aee1cedd59e620be35fe98b2085e5e9
Related-Bug: #1694671

(4 comments)

Seems to make sense? Certainly seems like something that could come up in production. I wouldn't have expected it in probe tests, though, since we run things one at a time..."}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-03-23 17:48:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-23 12:24:38.000000000', 'message': 'Remove race between checking for state shrinking and acting upon it

I saw a probe test fail during shrinking because the root shard range
table had both the expanded acceptor in active state and the undeleted
donor in shrinking state. No shrinking activity had actually occurred
on any replica of the donor.

The only way I could see that happening is if the donor sent the
acceptor state to the root prematurely. This could happen if the donor
checked that it was not shrinking, then received the acceptor from the
root, then sent its own range *and the acceptor* back to the root
based on a stale sample of its own state.

This patch also breaks the root updating into a separate method in
order to have targetted unit tests.

Change-Id: I4d3db021388daf12f59648ff06119a30d3444147
'}, {'created': '2018-03-23 16:28:02.000000000', 'message': 'Remove race between checking for state shrinking and acting upon it

I saw a probe test fail during shrinking because the root shard range
table had both the expanded acceptor in active state and the undeleted
donor in shrinking state. No shrinking activity had actually occurred
on any replica of the donor.

The only way I could see that happening is if the donor sent the
acceptor state to the root prematurely. This could happen if the donor
checked that it was not shrinking, then received the acceptor from the
root, then sent its own range *and the acceptor* back to the root
based on a stale sample of its own state.

This patch also breaks the root updating into a separate method in
order to have targetted unit tests.

Change-Id: I4d3db021388daf12f59648ff06119a30d3444147
'}]
commit_message:
Remove race between checking for state shrinking and acting upon it

I saw a probe test fail during shrinking because the root shard range
table had both the expanded acceptor in active state and the undeleted
donor in shrinking state. No shrinking activity had actually occurred
on any replica of the donor.

The only way I could see that happening is if the donor sent the
acceptor state to the root prematurely. This could happen if the donor
checked that it was not shrinking, then received the acceptor from the
root, then sent its own range *and the acceptor* back to the root
based on a stale sample of its own state.

This patch also breaks the root updating into a separate method in
order to have targetted unit tests.

Change-Id: I4d3db021388daf12f59648ff06119a30d3444147

fail. This patch adds the correct path to the validation.

commit_message:
Fix MySQL Open Files Limit validation

The MySQL Open Files Limit validation still checks the mysql config path that
was used before the service was containerized, which is making the validation
fail. This patch adds the correct path to the validation.

Change-Id: I58e8da19ee7d83921b2eb63024bb37df6e501be3
Closes-Bug: #1757409
(cherry picked from commit 21e6ba6cb73b61bd4063cc34bbf8cbeda287d7d5)

commit_message:
Allow to run tests outside openstack infra

The task run un-conditionally and the shell script
just echo empty strings which are then used for
ALL the deploys, breaking up deployments with wrong
repo urls.

Change-Id: Ia42a400a7729efa7e6b564c83d2de047a4f26887

commit_message:
update parse test to use reliable comparison

Different versions of setuptools seem to produce
different representations of the version specifiers,
so use pkg_resources to parse the values again
and then compare the resulting objects so we
aren't tripped up by rendering differences.

Change-Id: Ic67cc936208dbd96b6d811c6aa284fd87df5b118
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

fix

Change-Id: I98236acddf1f6bc206917e1c9aa8c53cb9a2ac0c
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Remove legacy-tempest-dsvm-cells job usage

The cells v1 job definition is being moved to nova and renamed
to 'nova-cells-v1'. The job usage is now defined in nova, devstack
and tempest repos so we can remove the legacy job name usage from
project-config.

Note that the related per-repo patches will need to be backported
to stable/queens (except tempest) to run the job there (the cells v1
job is currently blacklisted from stable/pike and ocata, so we're not
worrying about those branches right now).

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/549780
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/549781
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/549783
Change-Id: I5cfd9890856d289b23f79a3d1c1c01f0376ec897

[{'created': '2018-03-23 09:40:06.000000000', 'message': 'Adding ethtool command after binding dpdk drivers in Mellanox nics

Not like other nics, mellanox nics keep the interface after binding it
to dpdk, so we are adding ethtool command with 10 retries after binding
the driver just to make sure that the interface is initialized successfully.

Closes-Bug: #1756724

(cherry picked from commit 2ef379057f47a9ba89ac349e420fc017ada75e45)

commit_message:
Adding ethtool command after binding dpdk drivers in Mellanox nics

Not like other nics, mellanox nics keep the interface after binding it
to dpdk, so we are adding ethtool command with 10 retries after binding
the driver just to make sure that the interface is initialized successfully.

Closes-Bug: #1756724
Change-Id: I7e5efebf11a58d45707ff7a289a25297ac981a99
(cherry picked from commit 2ef379057f47a9ba89ac349e420fc017ada75e45)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-22 15:05:04.000000000', 'message': 'Update microversion-parse to 0.2.1

Early versions of microversion-parse were focused solely on parsing the
microversion header to extract a microversion for the current request.
Since then it has been used in association with some fairly generic
code to drive the microversion handling of the placement service. That
code is sufficiently genric that it has been moved into microversion-
parse so other people can use it.

Backwards compatibility has been maintain on the methods that
microversion-parse has exposed since the early days.

The updated version adds a dependency on WebOb, which is already in
global requirements. The minimum requirement in microversion-parse
is lower than the the minimum in global-requirements.txt

The placement service will be using features in the very latest
version of microversion parse, so the min is set here to the last
in both requirements and constraints.

microversion-parse remains apache 2.0 license, is managed in openstack
infra, has support for both python 2 and 3, and creates universal wheels.

Change-Id: I1b7d9357eee8f56f97b2dc8a894d360bf7cfc1ac

commit_message:
Update microversion-parse to 0.2.1

Early versions of microversion-parse were focused solely on parsing the
microversion header to extract a microversion for the current request.
Since then it has been used in association with some fairly generic
code to drive the microversion handling of the placement service. That
code is sufficiently genric that it has been moved into microversion-
parse so other people can use it.

Backwards compatibility has been maintain on the methods that
microversion-parse has exposed since the early days.

The updated version adds a dependency on WebOb, which is already in
global requirements. The minimum requirement in microversion-parse
is lower than the the minimum in global-requirements.txt

The placement service will be using features in the very latest
version of microversion parse, so the min is set here to the last
in both requirements and constraints.

microversion-parse remains apache 2.0 license, is managed in openstack
infra, has support for both python 2 and 3, and creates universal wheels.

Change-Id: I1b7d9357eee8f56f97b2dc8a894d360bf7cfc1ac

commit_message:
Sync snapshot's encryption_key_id with volume's value

Sync the snapshot's encryption_key_id with the volume's value just
prior to updating the snapshot's DB entry. This ensures the snapshot
DB entry isn't out of date in case the volume's encryption_key_id
changed while the snapshot was in flight. The encryption_key_id will
change when keys based on the ConfKeyManager are migrated to Barbican.

Closes-Bug: #1756139
Change-Id: I65abb8dd17de7633828b731d1cf1f2321a6f3e5b

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-23 16:00:54.000000000', 'message': 'Remove the use of upper-constraints for developer_mode

The gnocchi project does not comply with the OpenStack global
requirements process. Using upper constraints produced by that
process results in mismatches of requirements from time to time.

This patch removes the use of upper constraints for os_gnocchi
in developer mode. Deployers wanting to use constraints can do
so by using the pip_install_options variable.

Change-Id: I9862685898075d14f0160b0c8188835e88844d1c
'}]
commit_message:
Remove the use of upper-constraints for developer_mode

The gnocchi project does not comply with the OpenStack global
requirements process. Using upper constraints produced by that
process results in mismatches of requirements from time to time.

This patch removes the use of upper constraints for os_gnocchi
in developer mode. Deployers wanting to use constraints can do
so by using the pip_install_options variable.

Change-Id: I9862685898075d14f0160b0c8188835e88844d1c

[{'created': '2018-03-22 20:04:44.000000000', 'message': "Emit progress during swift-manage-shard-ranges find

On a large db, finding all shard ranges is expected to take a while. In
practice, with a 140-ish million row db that wasn't even trying to
continue servicing requests, identifying the 289 shard ranges took about
12 minutes, during which an operator may think the process has gotten
wedged. By dropping progress notifications ever 5 rows or so, we should
get messages every 10s or so.

Change-Id: I7d67e2bf5d4b8efc7131377581d25d6e884ef544
"}, {'created': '2018-03-22 20:13:03.000000000', 'message': "Emit progress during swift-manage-shard-ranges find

On a large db, finding all shard ranges is expected to take a while. In
practice, with a 140-ish million row db that wasn't even trying to
continue servicing requests, identifying the 289 shard ranges took about
12 minutes, during which an operator may think the process has gotten
wedged.

Now, we'll drop progress notifications every 5 rows, but at most once
every ten seconds.

Change-Id: I7d67e2bf5d4b8efc7131377581d25d6e884ef544
"}]
commit_message:
Emit progress during swift-manage-shard-ranges find

On a large db, finding all shard ranges is expected to take a while. In
practice, with a 140-ish million row db that wasn't even trying to
continue servicing requests, identifying the 289 shard ranges took about
12 minutes, during which an operator may think the process has gotten
wedged.

Now, we'll drop progress notifications every 5 rows, but at most once
every ten seconds.

Change-Id: I7d67e2bf5d4b8efc7131377581d25d6e884ef544

commit_message:
Update to fedora-27 for testing

We (openstack-infra) are in the process of removing fedora-26 from our
testing infrastructure. Update testing to use fedora-27 nodes.

Change-Id: I0a293849140bd2929dbcdb31fa08573802e5c61c
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/547107/
Depends-On: I148b1c8e265b327d60d76f88c036b032af014930
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-22 20:04:44.000000000', 'message': "Tolerate stale reads in manage_shard_ranges

Large DBs tend to have a lot of lock contention. Fortunately, we don't
really need the most up-to-date information possible; looking for shard
ranges always deals in approximations and inconsistent state, anyway.

Change-Id: I7cf6ccc42611b9bd4db8487038fe170f64df43a7
"}]
commit_message:
Tolerate stale reads in manage_shard_ranges

Large DBs tend to have a lot of lock contention. Fortunately, we don't
really need the most up-to-date information possible; looking for shard
ranges always deals in approximations and inconsistent state, anyway.

Change-Id: I7cf6ccc42611b9bd4db8487038fe170f64df43a7

commit_message:
Add a retention policy (age) when purging shadow tables

This submission changes the --all default parameter in the purge shadow tables
cron to a '--before <date>' allowing to define a retention policy. Age name was
used as puppet-cinder already use it so to have a consitancy across the
projects.

Also, it's added the option --all-cells causing the purge to be applied
against all cell databases.

Co-Authored-By: Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovat@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I2dcf37417c36fb8b1bde207c60d22d580005715c

[{'created': '2018-03-21 01:47:56.000000000', 'message': "Add [placement]/region_name to compute manager placement config check

Change https://review.openstack.org/#/c/492247/ in queens deprecated the
[placement]/os_region_name config option and you should be using
'region_name' in that group now, and you'll get a deprecation warning if
using 'os_region_name', but if you do that, nova-compute fails to start.

This patch fix the bug by adding [placement]/region_name to the check.

Change-Id: Iea7d5d0d6907adbcb236dc43b5af7469de2ba78b
Closes-Bug: #1757273

commit_message:
Change compute mgr placement check to region_name

Change https://review.openstack.org/#/c/492247/ in queens deprecated the
[placement]/os_region_name config option and you should be using
'region_name' in that group now, and you'll get a deprecation warning if
using 'os_region_name', but if you do that, nova-compute fails to start.

This patch fix the bug by adding [placement]/region_name to the check.

Change-Id: Iea7d5d0d6907adbcb236dc43b5af7469de2ba78b
Closes-Bug: #1757273

commit_message:
Remove redundant acl_config entry

/home/gerrit2/acls/openstack/openstacksdk.config is the default location
for openstack/openstacksdk. We can remove this line.

Change-Id: If16bf10b2f5176fe3485e9d826998e09efd00548

This patch refactors libvirt driver with the following strategies;

1. We can omit the else to save indents in the following function.

------
function():
  if A:
    return B
  else:
    ...long codes...
    return C
------

2. We can take the latter for the following code blocks.

------
if A:
  ...long codes...
  return B

else:
  return C
------
------
if not A:
  return C

...long codes...
return B
------

commit_message:
trivial: omit condition evaluations

This patch refactors libvirt driver with the following strategies;

1. We can omit the else to save indents in the following function.

------
function():
  if A:
    return B
  else:
    ...long codes...
    return C
------

2. We can take the latter for the following code blocks.

------
if A:
  ...long codes...
  return B

else:
  return C
------
------
if not A:
  return C

...long codes...
return B
------

Change-Id: I06f2078a8c98d35841bcdd17625e8b6e07e8c95c

This patch updates the default systemd service definition for the Octavia
processes. It increases the TimeoutStopSec to 300 seconds to allow more time
for the in-flight flows (failover, etc.) to finish and gracefully shutdown.
If the cloud has performance issues, flows may run beyond their normal
sub-minute runtime.

Change-Id: I5708c05db2c9f13491f5af0cd0b8c5632c537608
'}]
commit_message:
Update systemd service for longer TimeoutStopSec

This patch updates the default systemd service definition for the Octavia
processes. It increases the TimeoutStopSec to 300 seconds to allow more time
for the in-flight flows (failover, etc.) to finish and gracefully shutdown.
If the cloud has performance issues, flows may run beyond their normal
sub-minute runtime.

Change-Id: I5708c05db2c9f13491f5af0cd0b8c5632c537608

commit_message:
Remove references to v2.0 from external developer doc

The external developer document we have attempts to clarify various
concepts in keystone and make it easier for other developers writing
other services. Now that we've removed the v2.0 API, it makes sense
to update this documentation to refer to v2.0 in the past tense. Some
parts of the document seemed specific to operator documentation, which
has been either removed or reworked to the intended operators, other
service developers.

Change-Id: I809150f8b77a813e2300760fdcb1d11cfa8ca732

commit_message:
Remove references to UUID from token documentation

Support for the UUID token provider was removed when the Rocky cycle
opened for development:

  I76d5c29f6b1572ee3ec7f2b1af63ff31572de2ce

This commit removes references to the UUID token provider from the
token provider documentation.

Change-Id: I85aa4eac1098628f090b3e95a9234bc5777d274d
Partial-Bug: 1757151

Fixes https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1749838 for me'}, {'account_id': 17130, 'date': '2018-02-16 01:21:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7634, 'date': '2018-02-22 04:21:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2018-03-12 12:27:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

So I think this means we delete any ports we create, then re-create them... rather than unbind the port and re-use it next time.

This means the IP address you see in list instances changes as you retry on a new hosts. This is likely to break existing scripts that wait for the IP, then check for ssh to then come up, etc.

Now if we created the ports in the conductor, the binding vs create operation would be separate enough for us to do this kind of thing.

Having said that, maybe its something we want to break, I am not sure, hence the -1'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-21 01:37:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sorry for the late reply, I just saw the -1 (Gerrit dashboard hides it when there is a +2 on the patch).

> So I think this means we delete any ports we create, then re-create them... rather than unbind the port and re-use it next time.

Yes, because we don't really have the mechanics in place for unbinding ports that nova itself created. We have the pre-existing port logic, but trying to work this into that would likely get really confusing, especially when we delete the instance and don't delete the port because we flagged it as pre-existing even though nova created it. Which either means (a) this is broken until we move port creation to conductor and then figure out if we still have wonkiness to deal with there or (b) add another flag like pre-existing port but means something different, which makes me want to throw myself into a moving bus.

> This means the IP address you see in list instances changes as you retry on a new hosts. This is likely to break existing scripts that wait for the IP, then check for ssh to then come up, etc.

Do you think people actually have scripts that reliably work on something like this when we're re-scheduling before the instance status is ACTIVE? I don't think that's really something we should consider part of the API contract here.

Also, if I'm understanding this correctly:

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/queens/implemented/remove-configurable-hide-server-address-feature.html

We don't show the server address while it's building anyway, so it's a non-issue right?

> Now if we created the ports in the conductor, the binding vs create operation would be separate enough for us to do this kind of thing.

Sure, but when is that ever going to happen realistically?

> Having said that, maybe its something we want to break, I am not sure, hence the -1

Sure, I understand. I didn't think about the crazy script thing, but don't really think it's something we need to worry about either.

I was also wondering why we seem to make this so complicated to clean up after ourselves during reschedule, given the history on this same bug (and duplicates) and related attempts to fix it. I thought this is way too easy, I must be breaking something. But it's also possible we're just over-thinking this."}, {'account_id': 22623, 'date': '2018-03-21 03:09:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

 > pre-existing port but means something different, which makes me

 > 
 > > This means the IP address you see in list instances changes as
 > you retry on a new hosts. This is likely to break existing scripts
 > that wait for the IP, then check for ssh to then come up, etc.
 > 
 > Do you think people actually have scripts that reliably work on
 > something like this when we're re-scheduling before the instance

 > create operation would be separate enough for us to do this kind of
 > thing.
 > 
 > Sure, but when is that ever going to happen realistically?

 > sure, hence the -1
 > 
 > Sure, I understand. I didn't think about the crazy script thing,

 > either.

 > thought this is way too easy, I must be breaking something. But
 > it's also possible we're just over-thinking this.

Yea - and on top of that I feel like this is a pretty major issue, especially for older versions of Nova.
Maybe with the new scheduler improvements it won't be so impactful, but I doubt we will get away from completely failing to schedule vms, and having them rescheduled?"}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2018-03-22 16:46:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-16 00:26:11.000000000', 'message': "Always deallocate networking before reschedule if using Neutron

When a server build fails on a selected compute host, the compute
service will cast to conductor which calls the scheduler to select
another host to attempt the build if retries are not exhausted.

With commit 08d24b733ee9f4da44bfbb8d6d3914924a41ccdc, if retries
are exhausted or the scheduler raises NoValidHost, conductor will
deallocate networking for the instance. In the case of neutron, this
means unbinding any ports that the user provided with the server
create request and deleting any ports that nova-compute created during
the allocate_for_instance() operation during server build.

When an instance is deleted, it's networking is deallocated in the same
way - unbind pre-existing ports, delete ports that nova created.

The problem is when rescheduling from a failed host, if we successfully
reschedule and build on a secondary host, any ports created from the
original host are not cleaned up until the instance is deleted. For
Ironic or SR-IOV ports, those are always deallocated.

The ComputeDriver.deallocate_networks_on_reschedule() method defaults
to False just so that the Ironic driver could override it, but really
we should always cleanup neutron ports before rescheduling.

Looking over bug report history, there are some mentions of different
networking backends handling reschedules with multiple ports differently,
in that sometimes it works and sometimes it fails. Regardless of the
networking backend, however, we are at worst taking up port quota for
the tenant for ports that will not be bound to whatever host the instance
ends up on.

There could also be legacy reasons for this behavior with nova-network,
so that is side-stepped here by just restricting this check to whether
or not neutron is being used. When we eventually remove nova-network we
can then also remove the deallocate_networks_on_reschedule() method and
SR-IOV check.

Change-Id: Ib2abf73166598ff14fce4e935efe15eeea0d4f7d
Closes-Bug: #1597596

commit_message:
Always deallocate networking before reschedule if using Neutron

When a server build fails on a selected compute host, the compute
service will cast to conductor which calls the scheduler to select
another host to attempt the build if retries are not exhausted.

With commit 08d24b733ee9f4da44bfbb8d6d3914924a41ccdc, if retries
are exhausted or the scheduler raises NoValidHost, conductor will
deallocate networking for the instance. In the case of neutron, this
means unbinding any ports that the user provided with the server
create request and deleting any ports that nova-compute created during
the allocate_for_instance() operation during server build.

When an instance is deleted, it's networking is deallocated in the same
way - unbind pre-existing ports, delete ports that nova created.

The problem is when rescheduling from a failed host, if we successfully
reschedule and build on a secondary host, any ports created from the
original host are not cleaned up until the instance is deleted. For
Ironic or SR-IOV ports, those are always deallocated.

The ComputeDriver.deallocate_networks_on_reschedule() method defaults
to False just so that the Ironic driver could override it, but really
we should always cleanup neutron ports before rescheduling.

Looking over bug report history, there are some mentions of different
networking backends handling reschedules with multiple ports differently,
in that sometimes it works and sometimes it fails. Regardless of the
networking backend, however, we are at worst taking up port quota for
the tenant for ports that will not be bound to whatever host the instance
ends up on.

There could also be legacy reasons for this behavior with nova-network,
so that is side-stepped here by just restricting this check to whether
or not neutron is being used. When we eventually remove nova-network we
can then also remove the deallocate_networks_on_reschedule() method and
SR-IOV check.

Change-Id: Ib2abf73166598ff14fce4e935efe15eeea0d4f7d
Closes-Bug: #1597596

The README documentation implies that use-https and
https-service-endpoints are required when enabling SSL/https
with your own CA, SSL cert, and key. Update the README and
config.yaml to explain that config options use-https and
https-service-endpoints should not be set when using ssl_*
config options.

Change-Id: I2e0140f909ef2c57182895f37cf191b6bc80157b
Closes-Bug: #1754682
(cherry picked from commit 3384ddcb87a2c7621719c8844cf5a24a25936d48)
'}]
commit_message:
Update SSL/https documentation

The README documentation implies that use-https and
https-service-endpoints are required when enabling SSL/https
with your own CA, SSL cert, and key. Update the README and
config.yaml to explain that config options use-https and
https-service-endpoints should not be set when using ssl_*
config options.

Change-Id: I2e0140f909ef2c57182895f37cf191b6bc80157b
Closes-Bug: #1754682
(cherry picked from commit 3384ddcb87a2c7621719c8844cf5a24a25936d48)

Change-Id: I9d3d15411089fc020257b4021a5263a18433eece
"}]
commit_message:
Mock local directory testing for image conversion

A few unit tests hit the path in create volume that now checks for
and creates the image conversion directory. For unit test runs,
this results in a 'conversion' dir being created in the root of
the repo. This adds mocking to prevent local filesystem modification.

Change-Id: I9d3d15411089fc020257b4021a5263a18433eece

subject: DNM: builddoc: Treat '[pbr] autodoc_tree_excludes' as a multi-line opt
messages: [{'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-03-13 14:01:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-03-23 17:15:04.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nSolved it'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-13 14:01:53.000000000', 'message': "DNM: builddoc: Treat '[pbr] autodoc_tree_excludes' as a multi-line opt

We were treating this a single line, comma- or space-delimited option.
This was incorrect and was causing issues for projects like neutron-lib
when Sphinx 1.7, which switches from optparse to the stricter argparse
was used. In addition, this project was including comments in the
multi-line opt. These were being passed through but Sphinx < 1.7 was
simply ignoring them. These are now filtered out.

Change-Id: Ib1a37c4229583c47641aae31bd3bbf5672625898
Closes-Bug: #1753082
"}]
commit_message:
DNM: builddoc: Treat '[pbr] autodoc_tree_excludes' as a multi-line opt

We were treating this a single line, comma- or space-delimited option.
This was incorrect and was causing issues for projects like neutron-lib
when Sphinx 1.7, which switches from optparse to the stricter argparse
was used. In addition, this project was including comments in the
multi-line opt. These were being passed through but Sphinx < 1.7 was
simply ignoring them. These are now filtered out.

Change-Id: Ib1a37c4229583c47641aae31bd3bbf5672625898
Closes-Bug: #1753082

subject: Reintroduced nic feature based scheduling for rocky
messages:
[{'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2018-02-19 18:30:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-02-22 22:27:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(7 comments)

A couple relatively minor nits inline, but overall I'm still supportive of this. It doesn't touch placement and adds more tech debt to the existing pile of PCI management code, but not a huge amount and should be isolated to the /pci directory. I'm happy that the os-traits hw.nic traits are being used. ++"}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2018-02-28 11:33:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2018-02-28 11:39:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8213, 'date': '2018-03-01 14:29:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

Didn't get to read all of the spec yet, but I've been thinking about something similar for Hyper-V and the different NIC HW offloading capabilities available.

From what I've read so far, you're only talking about traits-like NIC offloading capabilities, and not consumable NIC offloading resources (in which I'm interested in).

Anyways, I'm interested in implementing something like this in the HyperVDriver as well. We've already added the necessary changes in os-win for this: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/531383/9/"}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2018-03-07 02:17:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

Yes this spec just focuses on the qualitive traits of a nic rather than consumable resources which would likely be better expressed as resources requests on the neutron port that consume from placement inventories similar to what is discussed in the network bandwidth based scheduleing spec. The spec primarily foces on libvirt as we previously extended libvirt to expose the nic feature flags but the intention was that other virt drivers could also support this feature.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-03-09 23:24:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

(6 comments)

meh, this will add more cruft to the PCI module and it is libvirt-specific (as is the PCI module), but at this point it looks like we've given up trying to do the right thing and replace the pci module with a proper thing that uses placement (and is therefore integrated into the scheduler).

So, I guess let's just go ahead and do this. At least it's using the standardized trait strings.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2018-03-14 21:21:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-03-15 09:33:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

Yup, I've reviewed this before and am still onboard. It would be nice to model this stuff in placement but we're just not there yet."}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2018-03-15 12:15:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2018-03-20 14:42:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

There are multiple ways to provide the feature, but I was thinking using the conductor for getting the port and passing the traits was possibly the best way. If you rather want to use the existing filter and do more tech debt for it, you need at least to explain why it's not possible to do what I said."}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2018-03-22 01:41:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)

tldr this spec does not ues placement for quantive tracking and traits for qualitive capablities as this is jsut a repoposal of the queens spec which was a repoposal of the pike spec both of which were approved and pike did not support nested resouce provider or traits.

if we want to redesign this for placement we can but since i am only ment to be work 10% upstream this cycle i dont know if i will be able to rewrite it from scratch until i check internally if i am allowed to spend more time on this.

i think we do a beter job of this today with the new apis we have however likely not in rocky as we have many depencies still outstaning. tracking pci devices in placement for one and allowing neutron ports to request resource+traits and finally moving the port creating into the conductor.'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2018-03-23 15:59:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-03-23 16:58:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Log health manager exceptions

The executor will hide any unhandled exceptions raised from the update_health
or update_stats methods. This patch updates the health manager to log those
exceptions.

(cherry picked from commit 24cd0070759fe094430d809167b2aa4964107a70)

Change-Id: Icc4d6c2cd7a93bb22ccab73e102db58ab423959a

subject: Fix crashing "console log show"
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 970, 'name': 'Dean Troyer', 'email': 'dtroyer@gmail.com', 'username': 'dtroyer'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 6476, 'name': 'Thomas Goirand', 'email': 'thomas@goirand.fr', 'username': 'thomas-goirand'}, {'_account_id': 13252, 'name': 'Dr. Jens Harbott', 'display_name': 'Dr. Jens Harbott (frickler)', 'email': 'frickler@offenerstapel.de', 'username': 'jrosenboom'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23913, 'name': 'David Rabel', 'email': 'rabel@b1-systems.de', 'username': 'rabel'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2018-02-07 08:28:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23913, 'date': '2018-02-07 09:07:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2018-02-07 13:57:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

David, you wrote utf-8, the value should be utf8. Probably you should try again. And yes, I did test this, and it did fix it for me (ie: I am running this patch in my PoC).'}, {'account_id': 23913, 'date': '2018-02-07 14:04:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> David, you wrote utf-8, the value should be utf8. Probably you
 > should try again. And yes, I did test this, and it did fix it for
 > me (ie: I am running this patch in my PoC).

Your right. But it still failes here:

>>> import sys
>>> import codecs
>>> sys.stdout.write("字")
字>>> sys.stdout = codecs.getwriter('utf8')(sys.stdout)
>>> sys.stdout.write("字")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/codecs.py", line 369, in write
    data, consumed = self.encode(object, self.errors)
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xe5 in position 0: ordinal not in range(128)'}, {'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2018-02-07 14:11:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hum... it seems that both utf8 and utf-8 are valid. So that's not the issue. Anyway, it worked for me. Not sure if the reason why I'm seeing this error is related to running bleeding edge Debian Sid or what."}, {'account_id': 23913, 'date': '2018-02-07 14:19:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Just tested the same on Debian Sid. Same error message. Don't understand it, though."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-02-07 22:06:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hmmm... it seems like we may have this problem in other places where we write non-static-strings directly to stdout (excluding the writing of object-store or image data).'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-02-07 22:07:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck   (sent the previous message too early)...is there a test we can add?'}, {'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2018-02-08 08:19:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Guys, I'm reporting the bug, and I send my patch, however, I'm sorry, but I have no time to add tests and such, I have enough in my plate with 421 Debian packages for OpenStack to maintain. Please do feel free to take over this patch and be co-author if you want to add a test."}, {'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2018-02-08 08:25:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2018-02-09 08:06:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-03-16 16:31:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-03-16 16:33:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

cliff already sets up proper stdout encoding in App._set_streams(), let's just use that.  I'll follow up this specific fix with another review to catch other occurrences"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-03-16 16:40:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-03-20 21:06:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2018-03-23 12:00:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck neutron fixed/reverted'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-07 08:28:21.000000000', 'message': 'Fix crashing console-log

Because of encoding issue, the "openstack console show log" is prone to
a stack dump, as explained in the bug report.

This patch sets the encoding output of stdout to utf8 before attempting
to print in it.

Change-Id: I4d8b0df7f16ee0463e638bb11276220e5b92023b
Closes-Bug: 1747862
'}, {'created': '2018-02-08 08:25:19.000000000', 'message': 'Fix crashing "console log show"

Because of encoding issue, the "openstack console show log" is prone to
a stack dump, as explained in the bug report.

This patch sets the encoding output of stdout to utf8 before attempting
to print in it.

Change-Id: I4d8b0df7f16ee0463e638bb11276220e5b92023b
Closes-Bug: 1747862
'}, {'created': '2018-03-16 16:31:25.000000000', 'message': 'Fix crashing "console log show"

Because of encoding issue, the "openstack console show log" is prone to
a stack dump, as explained in the bug report.

Use the stdout handle that has already been set up by cliff's App class
with a sane default encoding.

Change-Id: I4d8b0df7f16ee0463e638bb11276220e5b92023b
Closes-Bug: 1747862
'}]
commit_message:
Fix crashing "console log show"

Because of encoding issue, the "openstack console show log" is prone to
a stack dump, as explained in the bug report.

Use the stdout handle that has already been set up by cliff's App class
with a sane default encoding.

Change-Id: I4d8b0df7f16ee0463e638bb11276220e5b92023b
Closes-Bug: 1747862

commit_message:
Add missing 'target_obj' when perform policy check

Generally, we have to pass target object to ``authorize``
when enforce policy check,  but this is ignored during
our develop and review process for a long time, and the
potential issue is anyone can handle the target resource
as ``authorize`` will always succeed if rule is defined
``admin_or_owner`` [1]. Luckily, for most of those APIs
this security concern is protected by our database access
code [2] that only project scope resource is allowed.

However, there is one API that do have security issue when
administrator change the rule into "admin_or_owner".

1. "volume reset_status", which cinder will update the
resource directly in the database, procedure to reproduce
bug is described on the launchpad.

This patch intends to correct most of cases which can be
easily figured out in case of future code changes.

[1]:
https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/73e6e3c147fc357031834d0ac28478d061e6120c/cinder/context.py#L206
[2]:
https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/73e6e3c147fc357031834d0ac28478d061e6120c/cinder/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L3058
[3]:
https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/73e6e3c147fc357031834d0ac28478d061e6120c/cinder/api/contrib/admin_actions.py#L161

Partial-Bug: #1714858
Change-Id: I351b3ddf8dfe29da8d854d4038d64ca7be17390f

commit_message:
Solving permission errors due to directory ownership on NFS

We do the same work as the GlusterfsBackupDriver, uses chgrp+chmod to set
proper permissions on the directories if needs be.

Change-Id: Ic57c122311039af159c0cfc083e6e9349702d1e4
Closes-Bug: #1715456
(cherry picked from commit dd4c31f527e2c8f93fdfa55fe6713e0e32d94cc9)
(cherry picked from commit 0f3fb16ba3da0fdfc816887aa06920740824bc68)
(cherry picked from commit 9d06094c26dee3d5a87b5ad8fb70f0424ee432f9)
Conflicts:
	cinder/tests/unit/backup/drivers/test_backup_nfs.py
(cherry picked from commit a59d8fd93ffd4788685b5a4061c49668e0be1aeb)
Conflicts:
	cinder/tests/unit/backup/drivers/test_backup_nfs.py

IP address which is already not configured on device, it should

commit_message:
Don't raise error when removing not existing IP address

When privileged delete_ip_address function is called to delete
IP address which is already not configured on device, it should
not fail with any error.

Change-Id: I9247ac899a76e5d9a2962d2cb81279f2d6f16c0b
Closes-Bug: #1757259

commit_message:
Add nova-cells-v1 to experimental queue jobs

The legacy-tempest-dsvm-cells job is being moved into the
nova repo and renamed to nova-cells-v1. This change adds
the new job name to the in-tree definition of the experimental
queue jobs that run on tempest changes. A project-config change
will depend on this patch to undefine the legacy job name from
being used on tempest changes.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/549780
Change-Id: If6b7e59e71739361dcb0d246fca3fcf08af3514d

[{'created': '2018-03-23 03:43:07.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure the /etc/pki/rpm-gpg directory exists

This change ensures that the /etc/pki/rpm-gpg directory exists which is
not always true. This directory is required later in the playbook and
assumed to exist elsewhere throughout the stack.

commit_message:
Ensure the /etc/pki/rpm-gpg directory exists

This change ensures that the /etc/pki/rpm-gpg directory exists which is
not always true. This directory is required later in the playbook and
assumed to exist elsewhere throughout the stack.

Change-Id: Iae465b9076acccee4e26af48c1c7b3694b50b483
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Use soft authorize for 'extended_snapshot_attributes' policy

Cinder use soft authorize to control whether display
snapshot's additional attributes, this is broken during
policy in code changes.

Change-Id: I4b1b3432275defafcfc60465d3079bc9d70c4f56
Closes-Bug: #1756002
(cherry picked from commit d9c9f847173778db756c4045301666c27995f6cc)

commit_message:
Rename collectd-ceilometer-plugin and python-openstacksdk

Since Ceilometer support was removed from the
collectd-ceilometer-plugin[1], the repo name is misleading. This
change updates the name to collectd-openstack-plugins.

The pypi module for python-openstacksdk renamed a while ago to openstacksdk.
Update the repo to match.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/490823/

Change-Id: I6a2ba35c80f9b24772771ee0b708370ebab14bdb

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-22 23:09:21.000000000', 'message': 'Add CA certificates Secret and mount it

DevStack may be run with `enable_service tls-proxy` which will make all
OpenStack endpoints HTTPS. This includes creation of a DevStack CA
certificates bundle that then will be configured to be verified when
connecting to OpenStack APIs. This works well with non-containerized
deployment as the bundle is available locally in /opt/stack/data.

Things are different in containerized deployment use case as we need a
way to pass those certificates. This commit adds a 5th Kuryr Kubernetes
resource - `kuryr-certificates` Secret. DevStack plugin is modified to
add CA bundle there and kuryr-cni DaemonSet is extended to mount it.

Closes-Bug: 1758061
Change-Id: I7ac9d05868994cfc2a1aef4a8cd6c2148895e9c8
'}, {'created': '2018-03-23 09:01:52.000000000', 'message': 'Add CA certificates Secret and mount it

Our containerized gates started failing recently. Turns out some default
configuation was changed and `tls-proxy` service was added. This option
makes all OpenStack endpoints use HTTPS. This includes creation of a
DevStack CA certificates bundle that then will be configured to be
verified when connecting to OpenStack APIs. This works well with
non-containerized deployment as the bundle is available locally in
/opt/stack/data and our `[neutron]` section sets `cafile` option to
point there.

Things are different in containerized deployment use case as we need a
way to pass those certificates into the container. Effectively - we had
no CA certificates support for containerized deployments either in
DevStack or production.

This commit adds that support by including new Kuryr Kubernetes resource
definition - `kuryr-certificates` Secret. It is supposed to hold CA
certificate under `kuryr-ca-bundle.crt` key. kuryr-controller DaemonSet
definition was modified to mount the certificate into /etc/ssl/certs.

Changes also include implementing support for that in DevStack plugin
(placing the certificate in the secret and setting the `[neutron]cafile`
config option to point to that certificate).

Closes-Bug: 1758061
Change-Id: I7ac9d05868994cfc2a1aef4a8cd6c2148895e9c8

commit_message:
Add CA certificates Secret and mount it

Our containerized gates started failing recently. Turns out some default
configuation was changed and `tls-proxy` service was added. This option
makes all OpenStack endpoints use HTTPS. This includes creation of a
DevStack CA certificates bundle that then will be configured to be
verified when connecting to OpenStack APIs. This works well with
non-containerized deployment as the bundle is available locally in
/opt/stack/data and our `[neutron]` section sets `cafile` option to
point there.

Things are different in containerized deployment use case as we need a
way to pass those certificates into the container. Effectively - we had
no CA certificates support for containerized deployments either in
DevStack or production.

This commit adds that support by including new Kuryr Kubernetes resource
definition - `kuryr-certificates` Secret. It is supposed to hold CA
certificate under `kuryr-ca-bundle.crt` key. kuryr-controller DaemonSet
definition was modified to mount the certificate into /etc/ssl/certs.

Changes also include implementing support for that in DevStack plugin
(placing the certificate in the secret and setting the `[neutron]cafile`
config option to point to that certificate).

Closes-Bug: 1758061
Change-Id: I7ac9d05868994cfc2a1aef4a8cd6c2148895e9c8

commit_message:
Upgrade Apache Storm to 1.0.6

Apache Storm 1.0.x is used in Pike and Ocata releases.
Version 1.0.6 is the latest in this series and includes a number of
important bug fixes [1].

Also, switch from using `testr` to `stestr` for running tempest tests.

[1] https://storm.apache.org/2018/02/14/storm106-released.html

(cherry-picked from 4ab5f3a77ce9ab9fe8cfd6c05dd5a9b97ec95089)
Change-Id: Ib34fbf4ce282c106f63659ac2125cde6489e9832

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-23 13:30:19.000000000', 'message': "[Docs] Adapt the wording for disk requirements

Disks requirements aren't clear, and people can think it's
always required to have 1TB disk on cinder nodes. There is no
hard requirement there, so we should remove this requirement,
mark it as recommendation, and point its only for LVM backends.

Change-Id: Ic45a7799e5092653d70fce9f2b6b7ae3f03d8775
"}]
commit_message:
[Docs] Adapt the wording for disk requirements

Disks requirements aren't clear, and people can think it's
always required to have 1TB disk on cinder nodes. There is no
hard requirement there, so we should remove this requirement,
mark it as recommendation, and point its only for LVM backends.

Change-Id: Ic45a7799e5092653d70fce9f2b6b7ae3f03d8775

[{'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-01-31 17:12:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-01-31 17:44:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

Agree with the reason for the change, but I don't think this needs to a per-instance configurable"}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-02-01 08:54:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-02-01 11:28:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-02-05 13:38:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-02-05 14:14:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yup, this feature already exists [1]. Exposing this via nova is too virt driver-specific (it would only work with libvirt/qemu) and I can't find any data suggesting that customization of this on a per-instance is a necessary thing. In addition, the flexibility mentioned there comes at the expense of yet more complexity for images and flavors: if operators want to experiment with these tunables, there's nothing stopping them from doing so at the host level.

We should leave libvirt's work to libvirt.

[1] https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/commit/038eb472a0d970a17ccf4343ead0666df5c92f9d"}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-02-05 14:17:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Yup, this feature already exists [1]. Exposing this via nova is too
 > virt driver-specific (it would only work with libvirt/qemu) and I
 > can't find any data suggesting that customization of this on a
 > per-instance is a necessary thing. In addition, the flexibility
 > mentioned there comes at the expense of yet more complexity for
 > images and flavors: if operators want to experiment with these
 > tunables, there's nothing stopping them from doing so at the host
 > level.
 > 
 > We should leave libvirt's work to libvirt.
 > 
 > [1] https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/commit/038eb472a0d970a17ccf4343ead0666df5c92f9d

Looks like you had the exact same thought on the code [1] Good to see.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/484997/5//COMMIT_MSG"}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-02-06 09:29:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

My comments was because the original author choice to set the properties per image metadata where they should be set in flavor extra specs. That is the usage in Nova to allow isolation of hosts based on flavor specificity. (Where the usage of isolation per image is based on guest OS).

As I said I was surprised to see that patch in libvirt to add ability to configure queues size, it's really not the aim of libvirt.

So anyway if your preference is to do not support that in Nova, I'm not going to argue more of that, the operators still have a workaround."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-02-12 11:34:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-02-12 13:19:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

FYI some discussions are taking place to revert patch in libvirt which introduces ability to override default values of  rx_queue_size/tx_queue_size in libivrt/qemu.conf.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-02-12 13:48:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-02-12 16:25:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-02-12 16:41:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-02-13 09:45:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-02-13 10:39:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

I agree with Stephen about the possible solution for the short term.
Cheers,
gibi'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-02-13 11:03:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-02-13 11:49:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

(1 comment)

I still don't agree with this being a flavor extra spec, but I'm annoyed by how hard it is to get information on the rationale behind the design decisions. I'm washing my hands of it."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-02-13 13:38:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-02-15 12:12:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for your reviews both.

You made some good points, it's true that we can have in nova.conf some specific options to update the default values of guest XML. So I can't say anything, it's my mistake.

I don't see more advantages using flavor properties than what we already discussed and I don't share you "hate" of them. They are really good and important, what is missing is some kind of templates which can be shared between flavors (but it's an other topic).

I will try to discuss with some people which need that feature to see what are their thought on it. having in nova.conf or flavor properties.

About the alternatives section I thought it was for all the other ways to achieve the same "thing" without using Nova...But i will double check that and update it if necessary to add notes about the binding profile and flavor or nova.conf solution.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-02-15 15:25:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Sahid: what about bringing this issue up on the PTG? Will you be there?'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-02-21 10:10:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not going at the PTG, unfortunately."}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-02-21 10:10:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-02-25 21:45:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@sahid: thanks for adding the alternatives to the spec. I added an item to the ptg etherpad [1] to talk about these alternatives.

cheers,
gibi

[1]https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/nova-ptg-rocky'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-02-27 07:11:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2018-02-27 14:02:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

Just thinking out loud about the possible interface we would need to have for setting those very specific TX/RX issues, I wonder if the flavor is the best approach :( 
I know I don't help by providing an alternative but I think we should discuss with the community (if possible at the PTG) to agree on a consensus on the best approach."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-02-27 23:03:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> (5 comments)
 > 
 > Just thinking out loud about the possible interface we would need
 > to have for setting those very specific TX/RX issues, I wonder if
 > the flavor is the best approach :(
 > I know I don't help by providing an alternative but I think we
 > should discuss with the community (if possible at the PTG) to agree
 > on a consensus on the best approach.

We will have a chance to talk about the alternatives on Friday on the PTG as I added this to the agenda https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/nova-ptg-rocky L511"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-03-01 15:55:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2018-03-01 16:12:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

So the outcome of the PTG session discussing that spec was to accept instead of a flavor extraspec rather a new nova.conf libvirt option and ask operators wanting to have multiple possible TX/RX queue sizes to just create host aggregates with flavor mapping (thanks to the scheduler filter)'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-06 09:11:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)

Don't want to argue more of that. Let's make a chance to have this important functionality available for operators by using nova.conf. It's probably enough for today."}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-06 09:25:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-03-06 14:22:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(7 comments)

@Sahid: thanks for the update. I have couple of questions inline but the overall direction looks good to me.
Cheers,
gibi'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-06 16:47:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-06 16:49:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-03-07 10:09:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-03-07 10:10:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

Looks good to me. Couple of small issues and some nits, then we're good to go"}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-07 12:14:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-03-07 12:30:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

@Sahid: Thanks for the update. The spec looks good to me!
Cheers,
gibi'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2018-03-07 15:15:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-03-07 15:15:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(7 comments)

This looks good to me now. Couple of nits but I'm not going to hold up on them, personally"}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-12 12:43:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-12 12:44:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-03-12 13:16:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

LGTM! Let's do this!
Cheers,
gibi"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-03-12 13:46:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

There's a few grammatical things but this is OK with me. It's just a conf option in [libvirt] section and associated XML file element.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-03-12 14:01:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-03-12 14:07:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

Still good to me'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-03-13 08:23:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

LGTM. We would use this feature. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-13 15:53:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-13 16:11:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(11 comments)

There are several things in here which aren't clear to me, and I don't know why we'd add a config option for this if we can use flavor extra specs and/or image metadata, which would allow other virt drivers to standardize on the same keys."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-03-13 17:42:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: -Code-Review

(4 comments)

I'm on the fence with this. I can kind of see where Matt's coming from w.r.t. being consistent with the existin multi-queue extra specs, but at the same time, this isn't something that 99.999% of users would ever want to mess with and instead it's really just the developers of NFV-specific OpenStack distributions would ever override.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-13 17:56:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(9 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-14 08:36:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-03-14 19:24:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I agree with Stephen and Sylvain here to go with the host level config.
cheers,
gibi'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-03-21 17:26:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1

This has been through more than a few revisions and we seems to be back at where we are a few weeks ago. At this point, I'd like to just see us progress with this. The spec itself looks a-ok to me"}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2018-03-22 14:35:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)

This came up in the Nova meeting. Support the use case here, just thinking on the best way forward. Added a note on my current part baked thoughts.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-03-22 14:36:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-22 15:58:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-03-22 16:54:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

(12 comments)

A bunch of tiny grammar things, but I think it's worth mentioning migration as overwriting this, removing a non-alternative, and I think it's also worth saying you could make this a hot-reloadable option. Otherwise, I think this is fairly straightforward."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2018-03-22 17:18:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

-1 because I would love to confirm or deny if this works with live-migrating between a host with two different settings, or not. Mostly this is for user documentation, rather than the design as such.

Otherwise, basically good to go I think.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-22 17:21:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-22 17:21:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

commit_message:
libvirt: add support for virtio-net rx/tx queue sizes

Add support for configuring the `rx_queue_size` and `tx_queue_size`
options in the virtio-net driver by way of nova.conf

Implements: bp libvirt-virtio-set-queue-sizes
Change-Id: Ib74797fb22f3ec39b3efadf38633ef3e772e7f2a
Signed-off-by: Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui <sahid.ferdjaoui@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Update supervisor version lower bound

Supervisor has XML-RPC security vulenalbility. Upgrade to 3.3.3.
Refer to https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-11610.

Story: 2001648
Task: 6667

commit_message:
Add limestone to nodepool builder and launcher configuration

This makes limestone available for uploading images to and for testing.
max-server will be bumped once tests have been conclusive.

Change-Id: If630dca09b57f8ef842f2c01459e00bbf2d5c5dc
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/555470/

commit_message:
Remove tripleo jobs

Due to the issue in I72cab0131ccffb1989d6c1324d0c9b92166782da the
tripleo job is failing.  Unfortunately due to known issues there, the
tripleo gate is also blocked.  Remove this job for now so we can get
dib moving.

Change-Id: I07173cc11a98a946e3ee1418288136aa1f791f85

"}, {'created': '2018-03-22 16:35:12.000000000', 'message': "tox needs to pull from stable/queens

Updates the tox.ini to pull from neutron's stable/queens branch
instead of master. This should have been done when we first
branched queens here, but was missed.

Also fixes a UT to use neutron/neutron/tests/etc/policy.json instead
of neutron/etc/policy.json. Local UT passes without this change, but
zuul does not pass. It is not clear why this is required for queens,
but we did have to do this for master recently so at least it is
consistent with that, and it does make sense for a UT to use the
test-specific policy.json.

Change-Id: I864422fbed115871ed3b9de8e1702be9f6a255ae
"}]
commit_message:
tox needs to pull from stable/queens

Updates the tox.ini to pull from neutron's stable/queens branch
instead of master. This should have been done when we first
branched queens here, but was missed.

Also fixes a UT to use neutron/neutron/tests/etc/policy.json instead
of neutron/etc/policy.json. Local UT passes without this change, but
zuul does not pass. It is not clear why this is required for queens,
but we did have to do this for master recently so at least it is
consistent with that, and it does make sense for a UT to use the
test-specific policy.json.

Change-Id: I864422fbed115871ed3b9de8e1702be9f6a255ae

commit_message:
Pass user context to virt driver when detaching volume

A recent nova commit [1] changed the contract for the virt driver
detach_volume method, adding context. This updates the out-of-tree
driver accordingly.

[1] d2941bfd165055348dd584b630d4e631ef05e328

Change-Id: Idd9391570431c1a4b42894751f4e7b53f0c2595a
(cherry picked from commit 4387c0cf6a9521ae41081e366e7c592da573d93b)

commit_message:
Pass user context to virt driver when detaching volume

A recent nova commit [1] changed the contract for the virt driver
detach_volume method, adding context. This updates the out-of-tree
driver accordingly.

[1] d2941bfd165055348dd584b630d4e631ef05e328

Change-Id: Idd9391570431c1a4b42894751f4e7b53f0c2595a

commit_message:
deprecate fping_path config option

/os-fping was deprecated at API version 2.36, ``fping_path`` was
only used by this API so it should be able to be deprecated.

Change-Id: I7d3faae0013315d595386ff262cadf8b18f70c68

commit_message:
remove _cleanup_running_deleted_instances repeat detach volume

the volumes already detached during the above _shutdown_instance() call.
So detach is not requested from _cleanup_volumes() in this case. So the
call change to self._cleanup_volumes(context, instance, bdms, detach=False).

Change-Id: I833f259972dd2e0e6bb3bbaa0e5a78a93f59b076
Closes-Bug: #1756507

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I092758f7553860040990790a31651cd35affbc67
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Error when using ceilometer collector

cloudkitty-processor service error[1] when using ceilometer collector.
Because the ceilometer collector has been removed in cloudkitty repo[2].

[1]http://logs.openstack.org/21/555121/1/check/puppet-openstack-beaker-centos-7/404b6ea/logs/cloudkitty/processor.txt.gz#_2018-03-22_04_39_53_481
[2]https://review.openstack.org/#/c/548630/

Change-Id: Ibb3b13ab4a2342ee551343247e79f084678d3887
Closes-Bug: #1757945

commit_message:
Remove translate and a TODO

The TODO indicates may duplicate function but
all functions are actually used so no more to be
moved out, also, the log had a translate which
is not needed at all.

partial implement blueprint placement-extract

Change-Id: I905d621a1787b54a8946f7821bd02101dce14bc2

(32 comments)

Well, I'm sorry but I told you in the API meeting this morning that I didn't get this, so I've left just a ton of questions. This is really mostly due to my lack of understanding about how policy works in Nova, but if I don't understand it, I'm assuming I'm not the only one, so hopefully the questions I've asked will help to clarify the problem description, the proposed change and anything else in there that I've touched on."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2017-03-24 12:00:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review-1

While I understand roughly what is going on here, I think that this spec reads like inside baseball, and really isn't good for being a spec that will explain the situation to others, or be historical record for the change once we are all gone.

The intro should not try to be an abstract of the the problem. It should actually be a concrete example of "we have x in the policy file, which means we think it evaluates like Y. However it's really only evaluating like X. So if you change this part of it, you'd assume you'd get Z. But you really still get X." (which I realize is also abstract, but hopefully leads to a roadmap to make this more clear).

I also think the term scope check is basically used without any definition. It's not common parlance, so that phrase has little fixed meanings in people's heads. They are grasping trying to get their head around it and because it isn't clear it's hard to get the rest of this understood.

Scope check should be defined in the spec (probably in a dedicated section), with 3 or 4 worked examples, before it is used as common parlance.

I also am confused when we say we don't test any of it, because we do test real policy in functional tests like Matt said. That's been the way the code has existed for a while.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2017-03-24 13:19:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-03-24 13:24:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Verified-1

If we do this, we should just get rid of the oslo policy call altogether, and do only the Role check in middleware.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2017-04-12 23:39:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21:

(35 comments)

I'm getting a bit closer on this, but can't say I fully understand all of the parts about removing the scope checks, or the policy layer checking (whatever the difference there is, I'm not sure).

I think I understand the DB API issue now with the Trove example, that's good. And I think I understand how to fix that, but I don't see how the DB API stuff is all tied in with the policy checking in the API and how that changes with the check_scope method, and if those have to be done at the same time, or if they can be separate efforts.

I'm also not sure how much of the scope checking stuff conflicts with what Adam Young is doing in the projects:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/384148/

To support the is_admin_project thing."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2017-04-13 14:23:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

(22 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2017-04-13 14:48:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2017-12-03 16:05:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21: Code-Review-1

I realize that this has sat for al ong while, but I figure it is worth chiming in.

I think the whole policy mechanism should be split along the lines that you mention, with the scope check being performed in code.  However, the RBAC check should be moved into the middleware layer.

That kindof leaves nothing in oslo policy.  I'm totally OK with that."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-23 14:06:26.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Looks like this has stalled out. I think from the Rocky PTG, the first (next) thing we're supposed to be looking to support is system-scope tokens:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/525772/

And then I think we can eventually work on fixing the other issues mentioned in this spec like the fact that we often do policy checks *before* actually getting the resource on which we're performing some operation."}]

commit_message:
Add policy-remove-scope-checks spec

Here we separate the concerns of what resources user has access to and
what actions the user is allowed to do, but adding a new explicit scope
check alongside the existing policy checks.

The current is_admin_or_owner policy is very confusing, it is much
easier to understand after this change.

blueprint policy-remove-scope-checks

Change-Id: I1f6f1505683716c48a75f8a89ca96c4436fdef92

commit_message:
Mount openvswitch dir rather than socket

If openvswitch is not started (meaning the socket file doesn't exist)
and the docker container launches first, docker may create a folder for
the db.sock file which would prevent ovs from starting up later.  We
should mount the directory since ovs could be started after the docker
containers.

Change-Id: I0aaed5c73c1c1485ad61202f3fca53348ef5a669
Closes-Bug: #1757111

Unfortunately the openvswitch service was being configured via the

commit_message:
Add openvswitch element back in

The change Ie4f5d771a16ea453b470be8ea103b2bde4aa892a switched
os-net-config to be installed as a package rather than an element.
Unfortunately the openvswitch service was being configured via the
openvswitch dependency from the os-net-config element. The switch to use
the package lost the automatic starting of openvswitch on the nodes
which has manifested itself as intermittent issues on compute nodes when
network isolation is not deployed.

Change-Id: I0f865d4811919c19577c75615b66d7d8a1e685d3
Partial-Bug: #1757111

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-22 18:49:31.000000000', 'message': 'ScaleIO: Disable volumes in unsafe configurations

If ScaleIO backend pools are not configured correctly,
data may leak between tenants, since new volumes can
contain old data.

When this is detected, disable volume creation to
prevent data leakage.

Change-Id: Ic401c6458f73b108f16bfcb4843460b68a8ee504
Closes-Bug: #1699573
'}]
commit_message:
ScaleIO: Disable volumes in unsafe configurations

If ScaleIO backend pools are not configured correctly,
data may leak between tenants, since new volumes can
contain old data.

When this is detected, disable volume creation to
prevent data leakage.

Change-Id: Ic401c6458f73b108f16bfcb4843460b68a8ee504
Closes-Bug: #1699573

commit_message:
Fix nit found in monasca-ui

In some part in the code we use \ for multiline formatting. In the Openstack
style guidelines they recommend to use ().
[1]: "It is preferred to wrap long lines in parentheses and not a backslash
for line continuation.".
[1] https://docs.openstack.org/hacking/latest/user/hacking.html

Change-Id: I0c34cd9343e07aaec3bf543e9a1828db55d07246

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-23 15:05:31.000000000', 'message': 'Fix update of pacemaker container images during major upgrade

Currently, the idiomatic "download image and retag to pcmklatest"
happens at step 2 during upgrade. This doesn't work if the stack
is already containerized before the upgrade, because pacemaker
is still running at step 2.

Move the block to step 4, once we know that all pacemaker services
have been stopped, yum packages updated, and any potential docker
restart has been executed.

Change-Id: I85e11dd93c7fd2c42e71b467f46b0044d4516524
'}, {'created': '2018-02-28 11:58:35.000000000', 'message': 'Fix update of pacemaker container images during major upgrade

Currently, the idiomatic "download image and retag to pcmklatest"
happens at step 2 during upgrade. This doesn't work if the stack
is already containerized before the upgrade, because pacemaker
is still running at step 2.

Move the block to step 4, once we know that all pacemaker services
have been stopped, yum packages updated, and any potential docker
restart has been executed.

Also restrict the check for containerized deployment to step 0,
because it becomes invalid past step 3 because pacemaker deletes
its own container before it is stopped.

Change-Id: I85e11dd93c7fd2c42e71b467f46b0044d4516524
'}, {'created': '2018-03-06 16:12:02.000000000', 'message': 'Fix update of pacemaker container images during major upgrade

Currently, the idiomatic "download image and retag to pcmklatest"
happens at step 2 during upgrade. This doesn't work if the stack
is already containerized before the upgrade, because pacemaker
is still running at step 2.

Reshuffle the steps at which the various upgrade tasks are run,
while keeping the ordering guarantees of the upgrade flow:

  . Deletion of non-containerized resources happens at step 1,
    to allow calling pcs while pacemaker is running.
  . Pacemaker is stopped at step 2.
  . Docker images for containerized resources are upgraded at
    step 3, after the cluster is guaranteed to be stopped.
  . Pacemaker is restarted at step 4 as before, once we know
    that all resources have been upgraded, yum packages updated
    and any potential docker restart has been executed.

Also change the way we detect containerized resources, so that
the predicate still remains valid past step 2 when pacemaker
has been stopped and has deleted its containerized resources.

commit_message:
Fix update of pacemaker container images during major upgrade

Currently, the idiomatic "download image and retag to pcmklatest"
happens at step 2 during upgrade. This doesn't work if the stack
is already containerized before the upgrade, because pacemaker
is still running at step 2.

Reshuffle the steps at which the various upgrade tasks are run,
while keeping the ordering guarantees of the upgrade flow:

  . Deletion of non-containerized resources happens at step 1,
    to allow calling pcs while pacemaker is running.
  . Pacemaker is stopped at step 2.
  . Docker images for containerized resources are upgraded at
    step 3, after the cluster is guaranteed to be stopped.
  . Pacemaker is restarted at step 4 as before, once we know
    that all resources have been upgraded, yum packages updated
    and any potential docker restart has been executed.

Also change the way we detect containerized resources, so that
the predicate still remains valid past step 2 when pacemaker
has been stopped and has deleted its containerized resources.

Change-Id: I85e11dd93c7fd2c42e71b467f46b0044d4516524
