commit_message:
Add CellMappingList.get_by_disabled() query method

This query methods helps us to query for either the enabled cells if
False is passed as the value to the disabled argument or the disabled
cells if True is passed as a value to the disabled argument in the call.

Related to blueprint cell-disable

Change-Id: I3e0e1da186e4b3531b42e699ebd466280702d588

commit_message:
Generate user passwords with special characters

When we create user accounts in order to allow signalling back to Heat,
generate the passwords using a mix of upper- and lower-case letters, digits
and special characters. This should pass most password_regex filters that
users are likely to configure in Keystone, which was not true of the
previous method (using only hex characters from a UUID).

Change-Id: I7702d6ab550e4f1f53c4cea9f67ed0402afbd66d
Closes-Bug: #1666129
Closes-Bug: #1444429

commit_message:
[Docs] Uniform image on top

The workflow is on top of the pages, this is an exception. It
should fix it.

Change-Id: I40c9981f2c6b26fe5c2c61cfc45330cd476f2385

(4 comments)

I'm a no-vote for now because I think the team needs to put a stake in the ground wrt a) enhancements to the existing PCI manager code; which also talk about b) new trait- or inventory-ish additions to the [pci]passthrough_whitelist in same.

Some have expressed interest in allowing (a) to happen for high-demand features since sufficient nested resource providers infrastructure and/or generic device management won't be ready in Queens.  And (b) might be acceptable in that context because we're going to revamp the whole whitelist concept completely when we chuck the existing PCI manager, so it'll get "cleaned up" for free at that point.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2017-10-04 12:51:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2017-10-19 18:21:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 6681, 'date': '2017-11-10 15:42:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Just a note about a possible neutron side.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2017-11-14 15:37:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-01-30 08:53:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-02-01 08:33:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-02-27 06:40:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Patch Set 7 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2018-03-07 16:23:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2018-03-07 20:06:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I'm going to let Matt dump a hot load of placement all over this, but I'm wondering whether trusted VFs can coexist with untrusted VFs on a single PF?

Since the spec talks about aggregates, my understanding is that all of a PF's VFs will be a single type, either trusted or not, and you can't mix and match trusted and untrusted VFs on a single PF. Is that a limitation we impose because of nova scheduling, or is that at the kernel/device/libvirt level?

If it's the former, we'll have the same resource efficient problem that we have with pinned CPUs and that we're trying to solve with [1].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/543805/"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-07 20:10:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(10 comments)

This doesn't give me any details about what changes are actually required within nova, it just says "create port, operator ties a flavor to host aggregates...plus some changes in the libvirt driver".'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-07 20:25:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2018-03-07 20:31:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Other question (Sean? Brent?) - and this is probably just a gap in my understanding of Neutron.

For a trusted VFs (and for the existing PF passthrough mechanism as well), what's physically connected to the card being passed through is important. So a card connected to switch (or VLAN) A is not the same as a card connected to switch or VLAN B. When one does 'neutron port-create', how does that port end up being associated with the correct card?"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-07 20:37:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-08 14:48:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-03-08 15:15:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

I would very much prefer to build upon the work that Rodolfo did to standardize Neutron port capabilities using the capabilities:network dict on the port binding profile:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/504895/7/specs/queens/approved/enable-sriov-nic-features.rst@128

Then, we could add a new os-traits trait for trusted mode and re-use the same framework for requesting certain capabilities on host NICs.

-jay'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-03-08 15:32:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

FYI, I've pushed up a patch to add a HW_NIC_SRIOV_TRUSTED standardized trait to os-traits: https://review.openstack.org/550873"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-09 21:38:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

(3 comments)

In general I don't like the idea of adding yet more functionality based on the pci passthrough_whitelist, and we could solve this with traits and nested resource providers in placement, however, that's not really ready yet, and this doesn't seem all that complicated for the plumbing required (port binding profile has a trust flag, pci request spec has a trust flag, virt configures the PF on the host).

The scheduling details need to be fleshed out though in the spec. It took me quite a while to see the big picture after talking with artom and dansmith in IRC plus looking over the existing patches for this."}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-12 10:03:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-12 10:04:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-12 10:07:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(1 comment)

Thanks for your reviews, I expect that I have well understand that the agreement was to use the pci whitelist. I also have added more information about the scheduling phase and updated the alternative section.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-13 15:26:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(9 comments)

Adding Claudiu and Jianghua to see if this is something that can also be supported on hyperv and xenapi drivers.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-13 16:14:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-13 21:51:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-14 09:02:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-03-15 14:54:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8213, 'date': '2018-03-15 15:36:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Hm, so. It doesn't really affect the Hyper-V Driver. First of all, nova doesn't support Hyper-V VFs in the first place (will have to change that). Secondly, "trusted mode" VFs is pretty new in Linux as well (2016), and I haven't heard of anything like this in Hyper-V Server 2016 (it might have a different name though, it wouldn't be the first time). I could also take a look at newer releases to check for it.

But even so, it might not affect Hyper-V either way. In Hyper-V, the VFs are managed by Hyper-V itself. A vSwitch port can have a VF associated with it by setting a particular flag on the vSwitch port, and if there are any available VFs on the vSwitch. As for the promiscuos mode, Hyper-V can allow that through something called "Port mirroring" (we're currently using this for v-Magine, which is basically a Devstack AIO on Hyper-V, with Hyper-V as a compute node). I don't think there's any reason why Port Mirroring and SR-IOV can't be used together.

We haven't added the Port Mirroring feature in OpenStack at this moment. Might be a good idea. We only needed MAC spoofing until now.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-16 13:46:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-03-19 20:53:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

Well, we're getting *closer* to doing this with placement & traits.

I'm -1 on the [pci]passthrough_whitelist override, unless a pretty compelling case can be made for why we can't possibly do it any other way.

And there's still open questions about how we get the "trustable" trait onto the right PFs/VFs.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-19 23:51:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

> I'm -1 on the [pci]passthrough_whitelist override, unless a pretty compelling case can be made for why we can't possibly do it any other way.

The case is whether we can wait to do this all the placement way with nested resource providers and such, which is the long-term ideal, or do this the 'legacy' way which gives it a better chance of getting done in this release, and then transition later to the placement way when we're actually good at modeling nested resource providers in a working system (which I don't think we've done yet in any user-supported scenario)."}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-20 12:50:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-21 15:50:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(7 comments)

Mostly just spelling and wording nits, but otherwise a question inline about how the guest knows which VFs are trusted (device tags?).'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-21 16:16:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

I think we need some more thought into how the guest actually consumes this information and knows if it has a trusted VF or not. Do we do that via the netadata_data.json in the config drive / metadata service?

It seems like we could do something here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/2ec8c49f6cb4a0e7dba217e824c20d9c703d2105/nova/virt/netutils.py#L245

Where we get the 'trusted' value off the port profile which is stored with the VIF model object."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-21 16:17:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

*network_data.json'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-22 10:11:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-22 10:13:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

I think what you have suggested makes sense. The users may need such information to configure the bonding script.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-22 16:39:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-22 19:04:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

(7 comments)

I'm good with this now. Just need to fix the docs build failure."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-22 19:13:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-22 19:15:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-23 11:03:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-23 11:06:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Published edit on patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-23 11:07:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-03-23 12:53:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review+2

(4 comments)

OK with me, thanks for the updates Sahid.

-jay'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-23 13:09:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-23 13:12:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

(1 comment)'}]

commit_message:
virt: allow instances to be booted with trusted VFs

The inability to modify VF mac addresses in the guest prevents the
users from being able to setup up two VFs in a fail-over bond. This
spec aims to provide a way for users to boot instances with trusted
VFs.

APIImpact

Co-Authored-By: Vladik Romanovsky <vromanso@redhat.com>
Implements blueprint sriov-trusted-vfs
Change-Id: Ia00f88368e11f8af73692e1d4b50d85fca7941dc

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-21 00:49:12.000000000', 'message': "Fix entropy problems with OS::Random::String

When generating a random string, once we had selected from the various
required pools, we continued by selecting a pool at random and then
selecting a character from that pool at random. This did not take into
account the differing sizes of the available pools, nor the fact that the
same character could appear in multiple pools, which resulted in a
non-uniform probability distribution of characters. Since users mostly make
use of this feature to generate default passwords for services they are
deploying, this would result in the generated passwords having slightly
less entropy than expected (and pathological cases were possible).

Rectify this by always selecting non-constrained characters from a single
combined pool, and by ensuring that each character appears only once in any
pool we're selecting from.

Since we also want to use this method to generate passwords for OpenStack
Users, the new implementation is in a separate module in heat.common rather
than mixed in with the resource's logic. Also, use a StringIO object to
collect the characters rather than repeatedly appending to a string.

Change-Id: Ia7b63e72c1e3c0649290caf4fea8a32f7f89560b
Closes-Bug: #1757300
Related-Bug: #1666129
Related-Bug: #1444429

commit_message:
Fix entropy problems with OS::Random::String

When generating a random string, once we had selected from the various
required pools, we continued by selecting a pool at random and then
selecting a character from that pool at random. This did not take into
account the differing sizes of the available pools, nor the fact that the
same character could appear in multiple pools, which resulted in a
non-uniform probability distribution of characters. Since users mostly make
use of this feature to generate default passwords for services they are
deploying, this would result in the generated passwords having slightly
less entropy than expected (and pathological cases were possible).

Rectify this by always selecting non-constrained characters from a single
combined pool, and by ensuring that each character appears only once in any
pool we're selecting from.

Since we also want to use this method to generate passwords for OpenStack
Users, the new implementation is in a separate module in heat.common rather
than mixed in with the resource's logic. Also, use a StringIO object to
collect the characters rather than repeatedly appending to a string.

Change-Id: Ia7b63e72c1e3c0649290caf4fea8a32f7f89560b
Closes-Bug: #1757300
Related-Bug: #1666129
Related-Bug: #1444429

commit_message:
Adds Octavia to OSClient

This patch is the foundation for adding Octavia based scenarios.
The Octavia is now a top-level project and starting from it's v2 API,
No longer works as a neutron-lbaas provider.

This means that in order to interact with it, one should use
python-octaviaclient instead of python-neutronclient

[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/load-balancer/v2/#service-endpoints

Change-Id: Ia7a83ebe37a49e58400620b7ed3dedac209664f8
(cherry picked from commit 0be028b344ba4ec97c8f1a7f9098ad4fa3156922)

commit_message:
DNM: consume neutron-lib db utils

DO NOT MERGE; for testing at the moment

This patch consumes the functions rehomed from neutron.db._utils into
neutron_lib.db.utils.

Change-Id: I25ba3397af1ff95211863fd274118d35bbc2a709

commit_message:
Remove enable_legacy_telemetry and test Gnocchi/Panko in Xenial

At the moment, the scenarios for Xenial are not testing the new
Gnocchi and Panko stack in Xenial.  This patch adds testing for
them in order to bring them in par with the CentOS feature testing.

Change-Id: I1a5935e8fdd0e8aa13d0df592783f5438fc833b4

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-16 02:31:23.000000000', 'message': 'Fix the error message in _validate_no_ip_change

The validation is for existing ip == configured ip address but
the error message prints the value of CONF.network_cidr.

This patch changes the message to print the local_ip used in the
config.

Closes-Bug: #1756225
Change-Id: I045d72e48d63ab5b25858b5886578e18637c8d43
'}]
commit_message:
Fix the error message in _validate_no_ip_change

The validation is for existing ip == configured ip address but
the error message prints the value of CONF.network_cidr.

This patch changes the message to print the local_ip used in the
config.

Closes-Bug: #1756225
Change-Id: I045d72e48d63ab5b25858b5886578e18637c8d43

commit_message:
Add tempest plugin

This patch set adds tempest plugin to register existing tempest
tests of watcherclient. It is also required to let devstack-tempest
job to launch watcherclient functional tests.

Change-Id: I4d906fd597048bb37803a2bb42f8357502cf1b76

commit_message:
Improve mocking in REST API tests (test_swift)

The current REST API tests have a lot of rooms to be improved like:
- mocking the whole module of the API wrapper
- Unnecesary setUp()
- Test data should not be accessed directly via TestData

This commit improves test/unit/api/rest/test_swift.py.

Change-Id: I3532abee7febafea0f4cdc6ebfcc62f3cecd52eb
Partial-Bug: #1752917

commit_message:
Update the CirrOS image to 0.4.0.

Both CirrOS releases 0.3.4 and 0.3.5 are inconsistently used. Now all
sample scenarios will use the latest stable 0.4.0 release. The
image_location setting has also been converted into a Jinja template
variable.

Change-Id: Ic2ea83329d9fe774a5a666c4e988487ef502ce7f
Closes-Bug: 1751322

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-05 17:27:38.000000000', 'message': 'ovs-fw: Fix firewall blink

Previously, when security group was updated for given port, the firewall
removed all flows related to the port and added new rules. That
introduced a time window where there were no rules for the port.

This patch adds a new mechanism using cookie that can be described in
three states:

1) Create new openflow rules with non-default cookie that is considered
an updated cookie. All newly generated flows will be added with the next
cookie and all existing rules with default cookie are rewritten with the
default cookie.
2) Delete all rules for given port with the old default cookie. This
will leave the newly added rules in place.
3) Update the newly added flows with update cookie back to the default
cookie in order to avoid such flows being cleaned on the next restart of
ovs agent, as it fetches for stale flows.

Change-Id: I85d9e49c24ee7c91229b43cd329c42149637f254
Closes-bug: #1708731
'}, {'created': '2018-02-06 10:24:41.000000000', 'message': 'ovs-fw: Fix firewall blink

commit_message:
ovs-fw: Fix firewall blink

Previously, when security group was updated for given port, the firewall
removed all flows related to the port and added new rules. That
introduced a time window where there were no rules for the port.

This patch adds a new mechanism using cookie that can be described in
three states:

1) Create new openflow rules with non-default cookie that is considered
an updated cookie. All newly generated flows will be added with the next
cookie and all existing rules with default cookie are rewritten with the
default cookie.
2) Delete all rules for given port with the old default cookie. This
will leave the newly added rules in place.
3) Update the newly added flows with update cookie back to the default
cookie in order to avoid such flows being cleaned on the next restart of
ovs agent, as it fetches for stale flows.

Change-Id: I85d9e49c24ee7c91229b43cd329c42149637f254
Closes-bug: #1708731

[{'created': '2018-03-22 18:01:02.000000000', 'message': '[envs] Creating a spec from system environment variables

Deployment component had a noce hardcoded to openstack feature - create
a specification based on system environment variables.

This patch ports this feature to Environment manager and extends with
ability to configure not only OpenStack things.

Change-Id: Ic7b09a0a1f6d859f3db92400fb15ed9c1b69ea89
'}]
commit_message:
[envs] Creating a spec from system environment variables

Deployment component had a noce hardcoded to openstack feature - create
a specification based on system environment variables.

This patch ports this feature to Environment manager and extends with
ability to configure not only OpenStack things.

Change-Id: Ic7b09a0a1f6d859f3db92400fb15ed9c1b69ea89

commit_message:
Neutron scenario to delete subnets for the same network concurrently

This scenario, executed concurrently, should be able to trigger any IP
allocation race conditions in database layer of Neutron IPAM layer.

Change-Id: Icecfcd255fb83250cb77e8505f6b4846e005725c

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-22 09:56:40.000000000', 'message': 'Fix custom_nameserver must be a list

Fix undercloud-setup docs and defaults for custom_nameserver.
When it is not a list,
undercloud-setup/templates/ovb-undercloud-connectivity.sh.j2#n59
produces bad values treating each symbol of a string as a nameserver.

Related-bug: #1737555

Change-Id: I413ab6cbfbeb99fff5e6eb9f98077b18fa8bfab8
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix custom_nameserver must be a list

Fix undercloud-setup docs and defaults for custom_nameserver.
When it is not a list,
undercloud-setup/templates/ovb-undercloud-connectivity.sh.j2#n59
produces bad values treating each symbol of a string as a nameserver.

Related-bug: #1737555

Change-Id: I413ab6cbfbeb99fff5e6eb9f98077b18fa8bfab8
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-21 03:59:06.000000000', 'message': "Add service restart handler

A global var systemd_service_restart_changed is added which toggles
restart on unit file change for all systemd_services.

A systemd_services var 'restart_changed' is added to toggle restarts
on a per-service basis.

systemd daemon is not reloaded in a loop anymore, it is only
reloaded once, in a handler, when unit files change.

Consumer roles of systemd_service can listen to the handler
'systemd service changed' to implement additional orchestration when
service units are modified.

Change-Id: I803bca638c30696004f934ad1e28920786948f38
"}, {'created': '2018-03-21 03:59:54.000000000', 'message': "Add service restart handler

commit_message:
Add service restart handler

A global var systemd_service_restart_changed is added which toggles
restart on unit file change for all systemd_services.

A systemd_services var 'restart_changed' is added to toggle restarts
on a per-service basis.

systemd daemon is not reloaded in a loop anymore, it is only
reloaded once, in a handler, when unit files change.

Consumer roles of systemd_service can listen to the handler
'systemd service changed' to implement additional orchestration when
service units are modified.

Change-Id: I803bca638c30696004f934ad1e28920786948f38

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-20 20:03:05.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure output of shlex is quoted

Change I1e64647b3de86bc87a2a04cedf54ac83bbd4963d added "--mkfs-options
'-s size=4096'" to the build options.  It uses shlex which breaks it
up into arguments, but doesn't by default retain quotes:

 >>> shlex.split("--mkfs-options '-s size=4096'")
 ['--mkfs-options', '-s size=4096']

That results in the command being

 Running ['disk-image-create', ... , u'--mkfs-options', u"'-s", u"size=4096'", ... ]

thus dib thinks "size=4096" is the name of an element, and fails.

shlex seems to have a "posix=False" argument that fixes this for us by
retaining quotes:

 >>> shlex.split("--mkfs-options '-s size=4096'", posix=False)
 ['--mkfs-options', "'-s size=4096'"]

so use that

Change-Id: I309deb695a7aeb8cf708281ca2ab657986f313de
'}, {'created': '2018-03-21 00:52:32.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure output of shlex is quoted

Change I1e64647b3de86bc87a2a04cedf54ac83bbd4963d added "--mkfs-options
'-s size=4096'" to the build options.  It uses shlex which breaks it
up into arguments, but doesn't by default retain quotes:

 >>> shlex.split("--mkfs-options '-s size=4096'")
 ['--mkfs-options', '-s size=4096']

That results in the command being

 Running ['disk-image-create', ... , u'--mkfs-options', u"'-s", u"size=4096'", ... ]

thus dib thinks "size=4096" is the name of an element, and fails.

shlex seems to have a "posix=False" argument that fixes this for us by
retaining quotes:

 >>> shlex.split("--mkfs-options '-s size=4096'", posix=False)
 ['--mkfs-options', "'-s size=4096'"]

so use that

Change-Id: I309deb695a7aeb8cf708281ca2ab657986f313de
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure output of shlex is quoted

Change I1e64647b3de86bc87a2a04cedf54ac83bbd4963d added "--mkfs-options
'-s size=4096'" to the build options.  It uses shlex which breaks it
up into arguments, but doesn't by default retain quotes:

 >>> shlex.split("--mkfs-options '-s size=4096'")
 ['--mkfs-options', '-s size=4096']

That results in the command being

 Running ['disk-image-create', ... , u'--mkfs-options', u"'-s", u"size=4096'", ... ]

thus dib thinks "size=4096" is the name of an element, and fails.

shlex seems to have a "posix=False" argument that fixes this for us by
retaining quotes:

 >>> shlex.split("--mkfs-options '-s size=4096'", posix=False)
 ['--mkfs-options', "'-s size=4096'"]

so use that

Change-Id: I309deb695a7aeb8cf708281ca2ab657986f313de

Since we include redis in telemetry role, we also need
pacemaker for redis containers to start
correctly.

subject: Drop trove/sahara settings from horizon repo
messages: [{'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-03-21 22:14:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8478, 'date': '2018-03-22 07:54:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 24056, 'date': '2018-03-22 16:07:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2018-03-23 10:13:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2\n\nGood cleanup!'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-21 22:14:36.000000000', 'message': 'Drop trove/sahara settings from horizon repo

Settings related to horizon plugins should be documented in individual
project repos. We support local_settings.d mechanism, so horizon plugins
can provide their own settings examples.

One example is SAHARA_AUTO_IP_ALLOCATION_ENABLED. This option has been
deprecated and replaced by another setting. It is hard for horizon team
to track this kind of changes.

This is just a change in the example local_settings.py and there is no
feature change, so there is no deprecation required.

Change-Id: Ib28110246567808f9e9c0f99c6032f7bdc931643
'}]
commit_message:
Drop trove/sahara settings from horizon repo

Settings related to horizon plugins should be documented in individual
project repos. We support local_settings.d mechanism, so horizon plugins
can provide their own settings examples.

One example is SAHARA_AUTO_IP_ALLOCATION_ENABLED. This option has been
deprecated and replaced by another setting. It is hard for horizon team
to track this kind of changes.

This is just a change in the example local_settings.py and there is no
feature change, so there is no deprecation required.

Change-Id: Ib28110246567808f9e9c0f99c6032f7bdc931643

commit_message:
Add network-list to OSC

This change adds network list support to the python-openstackclient project
for the network-list command.

The zun command network-list is now:
    openstack appcontainer network list

Change-Id: I613ccff042e50a44cbbae074c706dc6e07867593

commit_message:
[FFU] Hook to allow user to pass a custom script for repo switching.

This allow the user to use whatever script is necessary to switch repo
in its own infrastructure during fast forward upgrade.

Change-Id: Ie74106de7a4d5cd761c2bd836c2aa03efa7ac091
(cherry picked from commit 2587cb4acf44d9b64ff2cabab8b056f66812d45b)

commit_message:
Remove some unused parameters in parameters.yaml

The parameters 'all_tenants' and 'vol_type_id' are unused, so remove
them. Besides, move volume_type from path to body which is only used by
api "Volume manage extension" in body.

Change-Id: I66718cf5558a2c12f7cfe336000314291a6820ee

[{'created': '2018-01-29 00:04:18.000000000', 'message': 'Not use thread alloc policy for emulator thread

When CPUEmulatorThreadsPolicy and CPUThreadAllocationPolicy were both
set to isolate, pcpus for emulator threads were also allocated along
with thread isolation policy. (i.e. only chosen from a siblings_set
where full threads are available.)

For optimization purpose, this patch allows in that case to choose
pcpus from non-fully siblings_set for emulator threads by considering

'}, {'created': '2018-02-07 03:47:58.000000000', 'message': 'Not use thread alloc policy for emulator thread

When CPUEmulatorThreadsPolicy and CPUThreadAllocationPolicy were both
set to isolate, pcpus for emulator threads were also allocated
according to the thread isolation policy. (i.e. only chosen from a
siblings_set where full threads are available.)

For optimization purposes, this patch allows emulator threads and the
VM's I/O threads to be collocated on the same sibling sets of pCPUs
even when both I/O thread and emulator thread are set to "isolate".

Note that this patch adds a new function of _get_reserved(), where
cpus are reserved for I/O thread and emulator thread, pulling the part
out from _get_pinning().

Change-Id: I23a5142398900873364bb07d8e91595d02a7a13d
Closes-Bug: #1746393
'}]
commit_message:
Not use thread alloc policy for emulator thread

When CPUEmulatorThreadsPolicy and CPUThreadAllocationPolicy were both
set to isolate, pcpus for emulator threads were also allocated
according to the thread isolation policy. (i.e. only chosen from a
siblings_set where full threads are available.)

For optimization purposes, this patch allows emulator threads and the
VM's I/O threads to be collocated on the same sibling sets of pCPUs
even when both I/O thread and emulator thread are set to "isolate".

Note that this patch adds a new function of _get_reserved(), where
cpus are reserved for I/O thread and emulator thread, pulling the part
out from _get_pinning().

Change-Id: I23a5142398900873364bb07d8e91595d02a7a13d
Closes-Bug: #1746393

commit_message:
Configure project name, version, release

This is currently done by pbr and we want to stop doing that. Start
overriding this via the 'builder-inited' event instead.

Change-Id: Ia2bdd815aac91bc191a4b965c4d07ea5aafa2f84

commit_message:
Remove use of unsupported TEMPEST_SERVICES variable

TEMPEST_SERVICES global variable is not supported
by devstack since long back.
- I380dd20e5ed716a0bdf92aa02c3730359b8136e4
- I9c24705e494689f09a885eb0a640efd50db33fcf

Service availability of tempest known services will be
set by devstack with local check.
- I02be777bf93143d946ccbb8e9eff637bfd1928d4

This commit removes the TEMPEST_SERVICES setting.

Change-Id: I381dbd1c2887189333463eb75363937c7509613c
Related-Bug: #1743688

commit_message:
Populate ContainerImagePrepare variable

If the user does not specify an explicit container_images_file in the
undercloud.conf, the variable ContainerImagePrepare will be set with
the values required to run the image prepare during the undercloud
deploy run.

This uses the same ContainerImagePrepare variable interface proposed
for the overcloud mistral-driven container prepare
I1b485ff9491fe2b1cf850116f9133de8d05f3d40.

The actual image preparation will be added to undercloud_deploy.py in
a following change in this series.

Change-Id: Ie8543bed3363aac539cfd35e04e8dfaaa166ebc3
Blueprint: #containerized-undercloud

commit_message:
Use TLS by default with autogenerated certificate in the undercloud

This sets the undercloud_generate_service_certificate option to true by
default. Thus enabling TLS in the undercloud.

Change-Id: Ia5ef1be013380f9de19715702dc3d1e3279429e1

commit_message:
Increase total image size to 23G

To generate the overcloud image, we increased the size of
/var from 7G to 10G. So we need to increase the global image
size to 23G as well.

Change-Id: I11db23ad173ad81bc9392bbde8ff6e3cca7ef6a8
Fixes-Bug: #1756319

commit_message:
Enable sharding via own_shard_range in manage_shard_ranges.py

To enable sharding manage_shard_ranges, give a broker some shard
ranges and set its own_shard_range to state sharding, with an
epoch. Let the sharder daemon do the rest.

Also add more checks for valid state before enabling sharding.

Change-Id: I10d0248f9bc582621c915c9028c5a950681245c1

subject: Store epoch in shard ranges table
messages:
[{'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-03-13 19:25:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-03-19 14:43:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-03-19 15:04:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-03-20 10:14:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-03-20 22:37:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2018-03-20 23:48:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hmm, Tim makes a good point. It does make me wonder if we can just reverse the account/container naming of a shard to get to parent. As a brokers account and container name is stored directly in the container_info table.

Account should be easy as its just a prefix. Container is harder as it's the container name, so can't guarantee what characters where used... though we could change the container naming again. Where the first part is the parent containername base64 encoded and then a _. So we can simple split and decode?

then we can infer root from existing metadata stored in the container db directly, not need to store as seperate sysmeta and the data won't get lost on a delete."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-03-21 00:32:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Now I'm pessimistic about the persistence of *anything* in container_info when dealing with deleted containers... but at the moment we seem to really shy away from actually deleting shards anyway... so might be ok?

I'm kind of a fan of storing this sharding-related info in the shard-ranges table, I'm just not sure that it needs a whole *column*..."}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-03-21 16:27:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Workflow-1

Thanks for comments!

I'm going to try to peel apart the two changes (epoch, root container) so we can debate the root piece more.

I like the idea of maybe giving root its own row in the table. I'm nervous about inferring the root from the shard name because the prefix is configurable and could change. Maybe it is ok, IDK."}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-03-21 21:42:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-03-21 21:47:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

The test timeouts were due to the patch being rebased by gerrit onto latest feature/deep after [1] merged.

Fixed by rebasing on [2]

[1] https://review.openstack.org/552133
[2] https://review.openstack.org/555280'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-03-22 21:07:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-13 19:25:08.000000000', 'message': "Store epoch and root container in shard ranges table

Storing the epoch of a container in its shard range makes it available
when creating brokers to replicate to that container. This means that
when cleaving, the cleave dbs should have the same epoch as the shard
container to which they are cleaving.

There is no other timestamp in a shard range that remains at the value
of the epoch so it requires a new attribute in ShardRange.

Since epoch is now in the shard ranges table it makes sense to put the
root container there too. It is stored under the name 'parent' because
that is a more general description. We currently 're-parent' shards of
a shard to the shard's parent, hence use of 'root' terminology, but in
future we might not always do that and shards might have parents that
are not the root.

With this patch, all steady state metadata required for managing
sharding is encapsulated in shard ranges. Sysmeta is only used for
transient metadata such as the cleave cursor.

Change-Id: I4b8fec618df9b6df463b0be46ae27ac7486edd97

commit_message:
Store epoch in shard ranges table

Storing the epoch of a container in its shard range makes it available
when creating brokers to replicate to that container. This means that
when cleaving, the cleave dbs should have the same epoch as the shard
container to which they are cleaving.

There is no other timestamp in a shard range that remains at the value
of the epoch so it requires a new attribute in ShardRange.

Change-Id: I4b8fec618df9b6df463b0be46ae27ac7486edd97

commit_message:
Fix claims on non-existing queue on swift

This returns an empty list instead of an error if we try to claim
messages on a queue that doesn't exist yet.

Change-Id: Ia92774ef1c55a371e37fc845511a5dceb8f92c00
Depends-On: I7e2128f3a5608ed9a41d1e18bd72d771a2a4ddb3
Closes-Bug: #1754061

commit_message:
Add disabled field to CellMapping object

This patch adds a new field disabled to the CellMapping
object which would be used to represent the value in the
disabled column of the cell_mappings table for each record.

Related to blueprint cell-disable

Change-Id: I1263c5b85f36f65860b9efcfa082948a866ad751

commit_message:
Add EnablePuppet (defaults to true)

This wires in a heat parameter that can be used to disable the
baremetal (Puppet) deployment tasks. Useful for testing
some lightweight/containers only deployments.

Change-Id: I376418c618616b7755fafefa80fea8150cf16b99

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-23 03:15:02.000000000', 'message': 'Correct image prep for minimal containers

Both CentOS and SUSE have pathing and services that are assumed to exist
from our previous use of LXC images. This change adds the "rpm-gpg" path
if missing, and unmasks the "sshd" sevice on SUSE if present and masked
or disabled.

Change-Id: Idc5caf2030c0e50dfeb84e0648bec08d7f50b6b8
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-03-23 03:34:11.000000000', 'message': 'Correct image prep for minimal containers

Both CentOS and SUSE have pathing and services that are assumed to exist
from our previous use of LXC images. This change adds the "rpm-gpg" path
if missing, and unmasks the "sshd" sevice on SUSE if present and masked
or disabled.

Change-Id: Idc5caf2030c0e50dfeb84e0648bec08d7f50b6b8
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-03-23 04:44:35.000000000', 'message': 'Correct image prep for minimal containers

Both CentOS and SUSE have pathing and services that are assumed to exist
from our previous use of the larger LXC images. This change also ensures
netbase is installed across our supported distros.

* Imports the "rpm-gpg" packages if the directory exists.
* unmasks the "sshd" sevice on SUSE if present and masked or disabled.
* Adds the (setup|netbase|netcfg) packages to the base image

commit_message:
Correct image prep for minimal containers

Both CentOS and SUSE have pathing and services that are assumed to exist
from our previous use of the larger LXC images. This change also ensures
netbase is installed across our supported distros.

* Imports the "rpm-gpg" packages if the directory exists.
* unmasks the "sshd" sevice on SUSE if present and masked or disabled.
* Adds the (setup|netbase|netcfg) packages to the base image

Change-Id: Idc5caf2030c0e50dfeb84e0648bec08d7f50b6b8
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

[{'created': '2018-03-18 11:37:45.000000000', 'message': "Adding number of attempts to ethtool command

In some cases especially in bond of interface with the same
PCI address it will take a some time to override the driver,
so ethtool may fail if it didn't finish initaializing the interface.
So we set the attempts param to be 10 to make sure it'll run succssfuly.

Change-Id: I7e5efebf11a58d45707ff7a289a25297ac981a99

commit_message:
Adding ethtool command after binding dpdk drivers in Mellanox nics

Not like other nics, mellanox nics keep the interface after binding it
to dpdk, so we are adding ethtool command with 10 retries after binding
the driver just to make sure that the interface is initialized successfully.

Closes-Bug: #1756724
Change-Id: I7e5efebf11a58d45707ff7a289a25297ac981a99

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-19 13:27:07.000000000', 'message': 'Set ExternalInterfaceDefaultRoute when setting ExternalNetCidr

After change I3bdb7d00dab5a023dd8b9c94c0f89f84357ae7a4 was introduced,
External network isn't "special" anymore in the network templates, it
gets generated as any other network. The default IP ranges and default
route come from network_data.yaml. Whenever we override one, we should
also override the other, otherwise we get non-matching
settings. E.g. my deployment with custom
`undercloud_external_network_cidr` previously resulted in:

(undercloud) [stack@undercloud ~]$ openstack subnet show external_subnet
| allocation_pools  | 172.20.0.4-172.20.0.250              |
| cidr              | 172.20.0.0/24                        |
| gateway_ip        | 10.0.0.1                             |

...which didn't work out, the controllers didn't have a default route
created at all. With this patch, the default route will get
automatically pointed to 172.20.0.1.

Change-Id: I99cbb7c652e374cb5c256a706661ba7ce5038b87
Closes-Bug: #1756878
'}]
commit_message:
Set ExternalInterfaceDefaultRoute when setting ExternalNetCidr

After change I3bdb7d00dab5a023dd8b9c94c0f89f84357ae7a4 was introduced,
External network isn't "special" anymore in the network templates, it
gets generated as any other network. The default IP ranges and default
route come from network_data.yaml. Whenever we override one, we should
also override the other, otherwise we get non-matching
settings. E.g. my deployment with custom
`undercloud_external_network_cidr` previously resulted in:

(undercloud) [stack@undercloud ~]$ openstack subnet show external_subnet
| allocation_pools  | 172.20.0.4-172.20.0.250              |
| cidr              | 172.20.0.0/24                        |
| gateway_ip        | 10.0.0.1                             |

...which didn't work out, the controllers didn't have a default route
created at all. With this patch, the default route will get
automatically pointed to 172.20.0.1.

Change-Id: I99cbb7c652e374cb5c256a706661ba7ce5038b87
Closes-Bug: #1756878

There are still some HOT templates pointing to ocata and

This patch needs to be backported to stable/pike.

commit_message:
Add systemd roles to OpenStack-Ansible

The systemd_mount and systemd_service roles are a way for
OpenStack-Ansible to not repeat ourselves in the code.

It can also be used by other members of the openstack community,
and is therefore not mapped to our main deliverable.
We are still curating it in our group: these roles will be important
for deploying a cloud with openstack-ansible.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/552861
Change-Id: I098ccc03ff2e4a4bcb65e1f376f2c712b10c9c25

I'm good with this, but just curious where things landed with the delimiter revival."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-03-22 20:49:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I'm good with this, but just curious where things landed with the
 > delimiter revival.

I addressed that in http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128179.html (see my inline comments)

It's also worth noting that we never actually reached consensus on the design of Delimiter, probably because it still suffered from the "where do we store the quotas?" problem.  Reference: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/284454/

We're not choosing a new library over a mature existing one, we're choosing a new library over another one that was in its infancy and was trying to solve a somewhat different problem, or at least in a different way.'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2018-03-23 02:41:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-03-23 08:21:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-23 08:52:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Create a new project called oslo.limit

This commit creates a new oslo library called oslo.limit to help
services enforce quota based on limit information stored in keystone.

[{'created': '2017-09-12 19:21:33.000000000', 'message': 'Apply supports-rolling-upgrade tag for heat project

We like to apply supports-rolling-upgrade tag for heat since heat right
now already fulfill fallowing targets:
* The project is already tagged as type:service
* Tag with supports-upgrade
* allows operators to roll out new code to subsets of service
* Full stack integration testing with services arranged, right now
  we have an experimental job for multi-node grenade job with tests
  runs before and after upgrade. Which is green and stable. and works
  for ocata to pike and pike to master.

for heat service.

Change-Id: I70295ece435357af3ecae575233e1d09096f461a
'}]
commit_message:
Apply supports-rolling-upgrade tag for heat project

We like to apply supports-rolling-upgrade tag for heat since heat right
now already fulfill fallowing targets:
* The project is already tagged as type:service
* Tag with supports-upgrade
* allows operators to roll out new code to subsets of service
* Full stack integration testing with services arranged, right now
  we have an experimental job for multi-node grenade job with tests
  runs before and after upgrade. Which is green and stable. and works
  for ocata to pike and pike to master.
With above works, this patch propose to add supports-rolling-upgrade tag
for heat service.

Change-Id: I70295ece435357af3ecae575233e1d09096f461a

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 782, 'name': 'John Garbutt', 'email': 'john@johngarbutt.com', 'username': 'johngarbutt'}, {'_account_id': 1063, 'name': 'Ed Leafe', 'email': 'ed@leafe.com', 'username': 'ed-leafe'}, {'_account_id': 3153, 'name': 'Emilien Macchi', 'email': 'emilien@redhat.com', 'username': 'emilienm'}, {'_account_id': 4162, 'name': 'Paul Belanger', 'email': 'pabelanger@redhat.com', 'username': 'pabelanger'}, {'_account_id': 5638, 'name': 'Davanum Srinivas', 'email': 'davanum@gmail.com', 'username': 'dims-v'}, {'_account_id': 5660, 'name': 'Kurt Taylor', 'email': 'kurt.r.taylor@gmail.com', 'username': 'krtaylor'}, {'_account_id': 6159, 'name': 'Flavio Percoco Premoli', 'email': 'fpercoco@redhat.com', 'username': 'flaper87'}, {'_account_id': 8482, 'name': 'Colleen Murphy', 'email': 'colleen@gazlene.net', 'username': 'krinkle'}, {'_account_id': 10608, 'name': 'Matthew Edmonds', 'email': 'edmondsw@us.ibm.com', 'username': 'edmondsw'}, {'_account_id': 11564, 'name': 'Chris Dent', 'email': 'cdent@anticdent.org', 'username': 'chdent'}, {'_account_id': 11655, 'name': 'Julia Kreger', 'email': 'juliaashleykreger@gmail.com', 'username': 'jkreger', 'status': 'On the moon! [{'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-03-10 00:41:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-03-10 00:55:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck

transient issue: http://logs.openstack.org/13/551413/1/check/build-openstack-sphinx-docs/77d63b6/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-03-10_00_45_19_545621'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-03-10 14:33:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I thought the plan was this would NOT just be for PowerVM, but the whole platform.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-03-12 14:25:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yeah, it was originally thus (ish) in PS2 of [1] - then see ttx's comment (the fourth comment down) which triggered the change to a more general name.

I'm personally not opposed to the group being PowerVM-specific, so I'll +0 and leave it to ttx to swat this one down f'real.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/540165/"}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-03-12 14:38:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

yeah, I'm neutral here. Everything done here today is PowerVM, but it was suggested the group be more general so that it could include Power KVM as well in the future if need be."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-03-12 21:01:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Tony, was there some event that inspired this change that counteracts the discussion on the original addition?'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-03-13 04:47:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Tony, was there some event that inspired this change that
 > counteracts the discussion on the original addition?

Nope there wasn't an event that counteracts the discussion on the original change.  I'm trying hard to extract the emotion from this discussion, I apologise if I let it slip in.

I appreciate the intent to allow for further representation but 
It feels wrong to me to fragment things based on the ISA, Hypervisor or Operating system.  I'm not certain what the motivation is for forming the group, other than to produce OpenStack deliverables for nova-powervm, networking-powervm and ceilometer-powervm.  This seems better handled under the existing project teams rather than creating a new team.

Having said that my change doesn't suggest the removal of the project team (or winstackers which is equally poorly thought out) it renames it and explicitly defines the scope.

Bottom line I've been working on OpenStack on Power for 4+ years and consider myself a 'PowerStacker' (in terms of the ISA) but am not represented by this project team, and I don't feel a need to separate.  My Power work makes me part of TripleO, Oslo, QA or Nova not part of PowerKVMStackers."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-13 08:49:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

recheck

If there is POWER support work that is not under this team's umbrella, then I agree we could rename/rescope it... The reason I pushed for PowerStackers is mimetism with WinStackers."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-13 08:49:47.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2018-03-13 10:01:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

I like making this distinction, so its clear what the group does. 
Although I would like to see a +1 from edmondsw before we merge this one.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-03-13 10:37:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

Looks like Matt voted neutral. If there's existing work that this team does not include and there's no desire to join the groups then renaming and clarifying the scope makes sense."}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-03-13 13:50:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm fine either way. I had originally proposed this be for PowerVM, after all. :)

I will note that the intention here wasn't just to be about the *-powervm projects but also to include work in nova, etc. And though our weekly meeting [1] is focused on PowerVM today, I'd be happy to see that expand to cover Power KVM as well.

Whatever happens here, I hope we can make Tony feel like he is included. First, we definitely don't want to exclude anybody. And we were talking with Tony about doing some things together just the other day, which I definitely want to see continue.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/552132"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-03-13 15:05:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Tony's explanation has swayed me to be more strongly in favor of this group being PowerVM-specific.  And I also want to reinforce what both Tony and Matthew pointed out: It is NOT limited to the openstack/*-powervm projects. It definitely includes Nova (the in-tree PowerVM driver as well as direction/influence over common pieces to smooth its support), Neutron, etc.  It should also encompass whatever Tony is working on wrt PowerVM on RHEL, in terms of him being able to be involved in team discussions, ask for and propose fixes/features, whatever."}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-03-13 15:07:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-03-13 15:10:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-03-13 15:12:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I had hoped this could be a larger scoped team. I'm not necessarily against this change, but abstaining for now."}, {'account_id': 5660, 'date': '2018-03-13 17:20:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11929, 'date': '2018-03-13 17:37:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2018-03-13 18:21:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-16 10:37:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2018-03-16 11:10:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1 Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-03-18 10:59:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2018-03-19 09:52:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-20 08:45:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Majority reached, this will be approved on Friday unless new objections are raised.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-03-22 15:05:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2018-03-23 02:44:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-23 08:51:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Rename and clarify PowerStackers

This change renames PowerStackers and clarifies mission statement added
in I1b709623df535b662871e9db2bac59b6f55f5277

The project team name and the mission are in disagreement in that the
name and mission cover all POWER CPU implementations but it's clear from
the make up of the group that it refers only to the PowerVM hypervisor.

Change-Id: I95f76f90fa65d0f54fed69b75cb575575976b33e

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 782, 'name': 'John Garbutt', 'email': 'john@johngarbutt.com', 'username': 'johngarbutt'}, {'_account_id': 3153, 'name': 'Emilien Macchi', 'email': 'emilien@redhat.com', 'username': 'emilienm'}, {'_account_id': 4162, 'name': 'Paul Belanger', 'email': 'pabelanger@redhat.com', 'username': 'pabelanger'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 5638, 'name': 'Davanum Srinivas', 'email': 'davanum@gmail.com', 'username': 'dims-v'}, {'_account_id': 6159, 'name': 'Flavio Percoco Premoli', 'email': 'fpercoco@redhat.com', 'username': 'flaper87'}, {'_account_id': 6754, 'name': 'Mark T. Voelker', 'email': 'markvoelker@gmail.com', 'username': 'mvoelker'}, {'_account_id': 8099, 'name': 'Graham Hayes', 'email': 'gr@ham.ie', 'username': 'graham'}, {'_account_id': 8482, 'name': 'Colleen Murphy', 'email': 'colleen@gazlene.net', 'username': 'krinkle'}, {'_account_id': 8556, 'name': 'Ghanshyam', 'display_name': 'Ghanshyam Mann', 'email': 'gmann@ghanshyammann.com', 'username': 'ghanshyam'}, {'_account_id': 10343, 'name': 'Jim Rollenhagen', 'email': 'jim@jimrollenhagen.com', 'username': 'jimrollenhagen'}, {'_account_id': 11564, 'name': 'Chris Dent', 'email': 'cdent@anticdent.org', 'username': 'chdent'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 12404, 'name': 'Rico Lin', 'email': 'ricolin@ricolky.com', 'username': 'rico.lin'}, {'_account_id': 13629, 'name': 'Zhipeng', 'email': 'huangzhipeng@huawei.com', 'username': 'zhipengh'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-03-07 19:07:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-03-07 19:09:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

This will probably need some refinement, but I wanted to capture a simplified version to see if we can keep this going in a useful direction.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-03-07 19:44:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-03-08 01:44:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

I like the simplicity of this one.

I would still like an answer to the question of which project the plugin repos should belong to for governance purposes in projects.yaml. I guess it doesn't have to be in the resolution, but I don't want to have another argument about this every time. IMHO the obvious one to choose is QA since it collects everything in a single place, makes it easier to ensure a consistent naming scheme, and works equally well for verticals that aren't necessarily tied to a single project. Still, given the joint core teams I guess it's kind of academic, since there's really no special responsibilities for the 'owning' project's team beyond giving the ok for a repo to be created. Though that makes me even more puzzled why the QA PTL is determined to go to the mat to avoid any connection even on paper."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-03-08 11:48:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

> I would still like an answer to the question of which project the
 > plugin repos should belong to for governance purposes in
 > projects.yaml. I guess it doesn't have to be in the resolution, but
 > I don't want to have another argument about this every time. IMHO
 > the obvious one to choose is QA since it collects everything in a
 > single place, makes it easier to ensure a consistent naming scheme,
 > and works equally well for verticals that aren't necessarily tied
 > to a single project.

Ah, good point. I think QA owning the "outside-of-tempest" plugins is not the best solution for two reasons:

* QA has made it clear by both action and inaction that they don't want to own them for a variety of reasons.
* I think the tests should be owned by the projects because the tests test the project and ultimately projects are responsible for themselves. If a plugin exists for a general collection of trademark tests, then the trademark program should own them.

I'll make another version after there is more discussion. I assume this topic will come up in office hours.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-08 13:12:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-03-08 13:48:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)

responses to ttx within'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-03-08 16:48:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

FWIW I'd fine with saying that all of the interop-specific plugins are owned by refstack for the purposes of projects.yaml. There's a slight inconsistency there because Tempest itself would be the one thing owned by a different team, but it's definitely not the end of the world.

I really do think the roadblock is people reading more obligations into the assignment of a particular repo to a particular project in projects.yaml than is actually implied though.

The actual implications as far as I remember:

* The owning project is given the courtesy of weighing in on new repo creation requests.
* Contributors get to vote in the PTL elections for the owning project.
* I'm struggling to think of a third thing.

But if this is the sticking point then by all means let refstack own the repos."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-09 09:10:34.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from cd/simplified-trademark to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-03-09 10:00:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-03-09 10:11:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Update version attempts to address earlier comments while also clarifying how repository ownership could work, to address questions elsewhere about ptl voting rights and other concerns.

I checked with Mark V yesterday about the option of having interopwg owner repos and he said that was a thing that could work, but discussion with the rest of the group would be required.

As I said before: I think we can spend forever coming up with ways to use this problem to try and force people to resolve resourcing problems but that just causes us to cycle around as we each grind our various axes. What this proposal is designed to do is provide some structured guidance so people can just get on with getting things done without risk of their work being later rejected or discovering that we created loopholes through which lots of work can be added to a team that won't be able to cope.

The end goals we (or at least me) are trying to support here is a clear path for teams to become a part of the trademark program if they want to. This is a hallmark of maturity, durability and usefulness; a thing we would like many projects to reach. We help them by saying "here's a path, if you follow this one we'll do our best to make sure you don't get screwed over later".

We believed the previous rules did that, but they assumed a different structure and population in the QA team. This new proposal differs by providing not just more resources (by allowing a wider population) but more diversity in those resources. It also is flexible enough to not time out easily. If, for example, we eventually had all trademark tests in their own plugin[1], this resolution would still be valid.

[1] This is probably the end state that we should eventually reach. It has a kind of single responsibility appeal that I think we should strive for, but we can't get there from where we are now in one hop (or potentially ever depending what the future brings).'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-03-09 11:54:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

Thanks cdent and everyone, current version looks perfect to me. 

QA team will make sure we regularly review the interop tests irrespective of their location.

Next i am going to write few guidelines and best practice (in tempest or blog etc) to maintain the interop tests in better way but those might be specific to Tempest-like test and i think designate etc can consume those.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-09 13:15:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Clarify testing for interop programs

This provides an alternative to
I91315c3c42b8a329d1763f9de80aa3d0270ac044 to provide simplified
guidance on use of plugins for trademark tests. The coauthors below
represents the people who were activce in the creating and refining
these ideas.

Change-Id: I2e68c8e855e7c6c1e4f985f38a0a38de451407a3
Co-Authored-By: Graham Hayes <gr@ham.ie>
Co-Authored-By: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Andrea Frittoli <andrea.frittoli@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Mark T. Voelker <mvoelker@vmware.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jim Rollenhagen <jim@jimrollenhagen.com>
Co-Authored-By: ricolin <rico.lin@easystack.cn>

[{'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-01 11:07:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-03-01 11:32:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

nice, refraining from voting until there's some bikeshedding"}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2018-03-01 11:48:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

maybe sad but true response to john'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-01 21:29:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:
