(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6088, 'date': '2018-03-02 10:28:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)

As a first pass, simply not deleting the branches along with appropriate policies to ensure people are not caused additional pain by such a change seems reasonable.  I do not think this is sufficient to solve the issue entirely: for that, I believe a richer framework to define "support" is required.

In another context, I was involved in an effort to produce a definition of support that allowed different parties to engage in maintenance over time, depending on the nature of support warrants they wished to make.  This was considered a complicated problem, and a compromise was taken that "upstream supports foo for $time, where "support" means bar": this was an excellent compromise in the sense that it meant the conversation ended, but a terrible solution in that every organisation involved was unwilling to specify either what they were committed to maintain or commit to assisting with maintaining all that was described as "supported" for the timeframes involved.  Such a model ends up with highly variable differences in "supported" over the community, which can cause significant surprise or difficulty for downstream consumers.  As one example, the EU General Data Protection Regulation provides a statutory requirement that systems that store data must be "supported": if our internal compromise does not meet expectations, this may mean that EU organisations cannot use upstream components directly, or it may mean that despite apparent compliance, these organisations may find they do not meet the expectations of regulators.'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-03-02 14:09:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1955, 'date': '2018-03-03 00:21:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-03 09:07:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-03 10:14:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6088, 'date': '2018-03-03 11:12:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-03-05 16:16:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-06 08:47:13.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from stable-branch-eol-resolution to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-03-06 09:30:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-03-06 13:20:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6088, 'date': '2018-03-06 13:50:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-06 14:26:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

In the TC "room" at the PTG we discussed the tension between two conflicting objectives:

1- let the upstream development teams "own" the stable branch story for their component so that they can control which branches are maintained and are safe to operate / upgrade from

2- allow downstream users in our community to continue maintaining a branch they depend on in a collaborative manner (rather than force them to fork and maintain it separately)

Ultimately it depends how territorial the upstream project team is with something that will bear the same name but will not be maintained by the same exact group of people in our community.

Personally I think that if we rename the EM branch and/or disallow releases from it, it would clearly show it's no longer an upstream product, but just a downstream collaboration facility.

The upstream team should definitely be given priority if they want to maintain the branches themselves, but in the case the upstream team doesn't want it and there is a user group wanting to maintain a common branch for backports, what should we do ?'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-06 14:35:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-03-06 15:17:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-03-06 15:20:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-06 17:40:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

My main gripe with allowing a core team to refuse that a given branch continues to be maintained by volunteers is that it makes it very difficult for any group to work on extended maintenance on a branch of "OpenStack".

If, say, Canonical shows up to maintain Queens for the duration of their LTS, but has to negotiate with every team and ends up not convincing the Swift and the Glance team, that basically kills their effort.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-03-06 18:42:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > My main gripe with allowing a core team to refuse that a given
 > branch continues to be maintained by volunteers is that it makes it
 > very difficult for any group to work on extended maintenance on a
 > branch of "OpenStack".
 > 
 > If, say, Canonical shows up to maintain Queens for the duration of
 > their LTS, but has to negotiate with every team and ends up not
 > convincing the Swift and the Glance team, that basically kills
 > their effort.

It would limit their ability to do all of that work upstream, and it would probably remove their motivation to do so, but I don't think it automatically kills it because they could still collaborate upstream on the other projects.

I would like to hear from some other project teams about what their preference is. I sense the tension in trying to balance the desire to open the branches up for contributions with the desire for project teams to have some control over the reputation of the software they are building.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-03-06 23:58:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10905, 'date': '2018-03-07 04:06:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Wheeee!'}, {'account_id': 13629, 'date': '2018-03-07 08:47:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > My main gripe with allowing a core team to refuse that a given
 > branch continues to be maintained by volunteers is that it makes it
 > very difficult for any group to work on extended maintenance on a
 > branch of "OpenStack".
 > 
 > If, say, Canonical shows up to maintain Queens for the duration of
 > their LTS, but has to negotiate with every team and ends up not
 > convincing the Swift and the Glance team, that basically kills
 > their effort.

Agree with Thierry here that it will defeat the purpose if it is up to each team. But different companies might have different desires on an em branch, so the question is as a community effort how we can define the common denominator which means we can setup a policy for a set of projects that could meet most (not all) of the user's requirements. I think we could always start with the defcore projects and then if some other project is needed for correlation, then the company who request it needs to have one serving as the liaison to work on that project em branch. Incrementally we can build a baseline of a community extended maintenance release.'}, {'account_id': 6088, 'date': '2018-03-07 15:50:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-03-07 23:03:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-07 23:26:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(9 comments)

To summarize, I think I've gotten to the point of just saying, let's never EOL branches unless we can't land code on them.

QA may move forward and break compatibility in tempest, at which point we're left with just pep8 and unit tests as long as possible.

The existing stable branch core teams will stay intact, but their involvement with these -em branches will vary by project.

The -em tag is applied after 18 months and we no longer do releases on those branches, but the "appropriate fixes" policy can be softened to be essentially the phase 2 guidelines that we have now (bug fixes are cool, but features are not). And backports must go in order (master->n-1->n-2->n-3...).

For the other details about all of this, I think we have to shit or get off this pot. At some point the teams doing the work on this stuff need to put a stake in the ground and say, "never EOLing is our compromise, the rest you will have to figure out internally because the entire community cannot be beholden to a few snowflakes with unrealistic demands".'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-08 11:08:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> To summarize, I think I've gotten to the point of just saying,
 > let's never EOL branches unless we can't land code on them.
 > [...]
 > The -em tag is applied after 18 months and we no longer do releases
 > on those branches, but the "appropriate fixes" policy can be
 > softened to be essentially the phase 2 guidelines that we have now
 > (bug fixes are cool, but features are not). And backports must go
 > in order (master->n-1->n-2->n-3...).

I'd be fine with that.

 > The existing stable branch core teams will stay intact, but their
 > involvement with these -em branches will vary by project.

To make sure I understand... You're saying the $PROJECT-stable-maint teams would retain full rights on -em branches, up to them to further delegate those rights however they see fit. My fear above (about making it difficult to motivate new contributors to maintain an openstack series across the board) remains... But I guess we can kick the can down the road and cross that bridge when the dead fish is on the table and this is the right first baby step... (-EANALOGYOVERLOAD)


 > 
 > For the other details about all of this, I think we have to shit or
 > get off this pot. At some point the teams doing the work on this
 > stuff need to put a stake in the ground and say, "never EOLing is
 > our compromise, the rest you will have to figure out internally
 > because the entire community cannot be beholden to a few snowflakes
 > with unrealistic demands".'}, {'account_id': 6088, 'date': '2018-03-08 11:42:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> To make sure I understand... You're saying the $PROJECT-stable-maint teams
> would retain full rights on -em branches, up to them to further delegate those
> rights however they see fit. My fear above (about making it difficult to motivate
> new contributors to maintain an openstack series across the board) remains

I think it unreasonable to expect extended maintenance over all openstack projects: for the intended audience from whom volunteers are sought, for any given release there will be projects that are considered good enough to leave mostly alone and others that aren't quite ready for that level of stability in production.  I would expect bugfixes in the former (perhaps for years after deployment), whereas I would expect most folk who wanted to use the latter to make significant efforts to upgrade.

If only vendors are considered, extended maintenance might be a period of five to ten years, but new releases come every six months, and new vendor releases every couple years.  Most vendors would likely recommend customers to upgrade services that are difficult to maintain sooner than the maximum maintenance period, and maybe not so strongly recommend upgrade for services that only have the occasional CVE for extended maintenance.

For direct consuming operators, the choice is even clearer: there is some pain involved in participating in extended maintenance, and some pain involved in upgrading services and advising users of new features.  Where a service is easy to maintain, the choice might be to delay upgrade,  Where a service is hard to maintain, the choice might be to upgrade the service.

In combination, these practices are likely to mean that some services have much longer extended maintenance windows than others, to the extent that some services may not have anyone interested in participating in extended maintenance at all.  If it is required that all services must be maintained for the same period in lockstep, it may not be interesting for any organisations to participate at all, as the pain of maintaining a few things without collaborative support could be considered significantly less than the pain of committing to collaborative maintenance for *everything* for extended periods."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-08 13:21:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I think it unreasonable to expect extended maintenance over all
 > openstack projects: [...]

"all openstack projects" is not my expectation. For any interested group, maintaining an "OpenStack" series means maintaining the set of projects present in your distribution. For most it would be the set of projects in an OpenStack[tm]-powered cloud (as defined by the trademark program). That's less than 50 things, but more than one.

Having to engage with each of those projects stable teams separately and get accepted to participate in that specific series maintenance is likely to be a complex endeavor, if each team retains the right to reject parts of that group, or to refuse maintenance of a series altogether.

In the end I fear that we'll fail to grab the extra resources that would have engaged if we let them step up in a per-series group (rather than per-project and per-series groups).'}, {'account_id': 6088, 'date': '2018-03-08 13:41:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> In the end I fear that we'll fail to grab the extra resources that would have
> engaged if we let them step up in a per-series group (rather than per-project
> and per-series groups).

    That fear makes sense: creating lots of little groups tends to cause identity divide issues.  In practice, I think people will only contribute to branches they care about, so the actual patches submitted won't be affected.  If the need to coordinate per-team ends up being onerous, or if team rivalry gets in the way, that would be unfortunate."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-08 14:26:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I'm not proposing that all projects need to have the same level of engagement on the -em branches. But I am saying that the existing stable core teams retain their rights on the branches, and as ttx said, they can delegate to newcomers that get involved on those branches, assuming that happens; this whole "if you build it they will come thing" doesn't really happen in reality when it comes to stable branch maintenance in my experience; people want to consume from upstream for free w/o having to put any work toward it.

Swift already said that they won't allow creating new core teams for -em branches as they would consider that a fork, and others agreed with that sentiment, so I've flipped on the wording for the core team.

For the rest of what persia is saying, I'm not sure I'm following. Either it's more complicated than I can process right now, or just needs to be re-worded, idk.

I'm just trying to keep this as simple as possible: stop EOL across the board (unless you can't land code on said branch for said project), retain the core team, stop doing releases on -em branches, and soften the 'appropriate fixes' policy for those -em branches, but still just bug fixes - no features. If people want features on older branches, they need to fork and do that internally.'}, {'account_id': 6088, 'date': '2018-03-08 14:47:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> For the rest of what persia is saying, I'm not sure I'm following. Either it's more complicated than I can process right now, or just needs to be re-worded, idk.

Short form is that I agree with "we can kick the can down the road and cross that bridge when the dead fish is on the table and this is the right first baby step", but am speculating on the matter anyway.

Longer-worded explanation:

The current wording "After the upstream support phase ends, the core team for the branch will be turned over to essentially whoever is maintaining the branch." does not specify the identity of the whoever.  My opinion is that any sensible whoever will probably end up forging a common identity to work on many projects.  I read Thierry's fear as that these folk may end up splintered, each associated with project teams, and nobody associated with a broader "extended maintenance" goal.

For the purposes of moving forward, I suspect the current wording is fine.  As people who actually plan to implement this are identified, there may or may not need to be clarification about the identity and scope of extended maintenance contributors.  The absence of anyone currently engaged in extended maintenance makes it hard to come to a good consensus about how that group self-identifies.  It may be possible to influence future self-identification by setting initial ground rules, but we are having a hard enough time coming to consensus to allow anyone to propose changes at all, so let's do that first, and we can talk about ideal mechanisms for projects to interact with extended maintenance teams later.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-08 15:03:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> The current wording "After the upstream support phase ends, the core team for the branch will be turned over to essentially whoever is maintaining the branch." does not specify the identity of the whoever. My opinion is that any sensible whoever will probably end up forging a common identity to work on many projects. I read Thierry's fear as that these folk may end up splintered, each associated with project teams, and nobody associated with a broader "extended maintenance" goal.

That's all getting dropped in the next revision. We're not turning over the keys anymore, as swift (and others) have pushed back on that.'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-03-08 16:21:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We've talked about this for years, and talked some more at the
Rocky PTG. This adds a resolution to try and document / summarize
the outcomes of the Sydney summit, where I believe we essentially
came to the conclusion that the upstream team was OK with not deleting
the oldest branch (EOL) and would turn over its maintenance to
interested parties who may or may not be part of the formal upstream
teams.

Change-Id: I94b0421d8a489026300789b61b0293dd2e61726d

commit_message:
Add a resolution about stable branch EOL and "extended maintenance"

We've talked about this for years, and talked some more at the
Rocky PTG. This adds a resolution to try and document / summarize
the outcomes of the Sydney summit and Rocky PTG.

Change-Id: I94b0421d8a489026300789b61b0293dd2e61726d

commit_message:
driver-teams: Level playing fields, except drivers

Acknowledge our expectation for a level playing field but resolve
that it is neither necessary nor reasonable to require it of those
developing drivers for proprietary systems. Amend our requirements
to allow those developers focused solely on drivers recognition as
official teams by the OpenStack technical committee, so long as they
meet all the other criteria required of any official team.

Change-Id: Ia06863657be6b9071c404453a33800979d1288eb

commit_message:
driver-teams: Driver development can be level

Reaffirm that OpenStack is about enabling open collaboration and our
dedication to maintaining a level playing field. Resolve that, even
though development of drivers for proprietary systems is often
incompatible with this principle, those developers focused solely on
drivers may be recognized as official teams by the OpenStack
technical committee if they meet all the same criteria required of
any official team.

commit_message:
Increase the post-timeout to 3600 seconds

The default post-timeout is 1800, which is not enough to push images to
hub.docker.com.

Change-Id: If1e499c247f3eeb8452991cb18aea5b1fdad60a7
Closes-Bug: #1755416
(cherry picked from commit 864965c40044cab1e459e4f8692473940497be3f)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-21 13:05:11.000000000', 'message': "Fixes incorrect ownership of ODL TLS cert/key

Deployments were failing because the owner/group of the TLS generated
certificate and key were set to 'odl'.  This user and group does not
exist in a containerized deployment because the ODL RPM is only
installed in the container.

This patch leaves the owner as root for the files which works because
the files are only used to generate a keystore for ODL (which is owned
by odl), and the cert/key files themselves are never read by ODL.

Closes-Bug: 1757135

Change-Id: Ie5b9e98ea2fc16b820d56272653df4874e81cf68
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit e11804237e81c8488bd008603638d5f62758acb7)
"}]
commit_message:
Fixes incorrect ownership of ODL TLS cert/key

Deployments were failing because the owner/group of the TLS generated
certificate and key were set to 'odl'.  This user and group does not
exist in a containerized deployment because the ODL RPM is only
installed in the container.

This patch leaves the owner as root for the files which works because
the files are only used to generate a keystore for ODL (which is owned
by odl), and the cert/key files themselves are never read by ODL.

Closes-Bug: 1757135

Change-Id: Ie5b9e98ea2fc16b820d56272653df4874e81cf68
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit e11804237e81c8488bd008603638d5f62758acb7)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-21 19:55:10.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes ODL container failing to start due to missing etc config

The ODL etc directory was being overridden with an empty mount directory
before kolla_start copied the puppet-generated config files.  The
puppet-generated config files only include modified configuration files
and not all of the default config files.  Therefore ODL was missing
config files when it started so the container was constantly crashing.

This patch removes the unwanted mount erasing the /opt/opendaylight/etc
directory and moves the upgrade file to be created in puppet-generated,
which will be copied at kolla start time for upgrade.  The
puppet-generated dir is read-only, so the REST call to disable upgrade
flag in ODL will only disable it for the running instance.  Therefore we
have to use ansible to write the file again to disable it incase ODL is
rebooted.

Closes-Bug: 1755916

Change-Id: Ie380cc41ca50a294a2647d673f339d02111bf6b3
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 97173caf8f68695140d207c2ab88226fd86659dc)
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes ODL container failing to start due to missing etc config

The ODL etc directory was being overridden with an empty mount directory
before kolla_start copied the puppet-generated config files.  The
puppet-generated config files only include modified configuration files
and not all of the default config files.  Therefore ODL was missing
config files when it started so the container was constantly crashing.

This patch removes the unwanted mount erasing the /opt/opendaylight/etc
directory and moves the upgrade file to be created in puppet-generated,
which will be copied at kolla start time for upgrade.  The
puppet-generated dir is read-only, so the REST call to disable upgrade
flag in ODL will only disable it for the running instance.  Therefore we
have to use ansible to write the file again to disable it incase ODL is
rebooted.

Closes-Bug: 1755916

Change-Id: Ie380cc41ca50a294a2647d673f339d02111bf6b3
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 97173caf8f68695140d207c2ab88226fd86659dc)

commit_message:
Remove composable role config from testenv

The composable role configuration should come from the featureset and
not the test environment configuration. This file is included after the
featureset in the deployment so it may override the configuration if
it's set to false.

Closes-Bug: #1758180
Change-Id: Idad5fa6326f7c8c528ea4a971340ca2bdaa15f25

subject: Temporarily disable py35 jobs for trove-dashboard stable branches
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1004, 'name': 'Mohammed Naser', 'email': 'mnaser@vexxhost.com', 'username': 'mnaser'}, {'_account_id': 6547, 'name': 'Andreas Jaeger', 'email': 'jaegerandi@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaegerandi'}, {'_account_id': 13157, 'name': 'Zhao Chao', 'email': 'zhaochao1984@gmail.com', 'username': 'zhaochao'}, {'_account_id': 13252, 'name': 'Dr. Jens Harbott', 'display_name': 'Dr. Jens Harbott (frickler)', 'email': 'frickler@offenerstapel.de', 'username': 'jrosenboom'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 24791, 'name': 'Maciej Jozefczyk', 'email': 'jeicam.pl@gmail.com', 'username': 'maciej.jozefczyk'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 13157, 'date': '2018-03-22 01:21:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13157, 'date': '2018-03-22 01:29:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi, Andreas Jaeger, Mohammed Naser, could we just temporarily make the py35 jobs non-voting for the stable branches or are there something we could do with the zuul configurations inside the trove-dashboard repo to achieve this?

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 13157, 'date': '2018-03-22 02:47:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Please also help to review another try:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/555111/

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-03-22 06:05:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13157, 'date': '2018-03-22 06:20:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13157, 'date': '2018-03-22 06:45:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 13157, 'date': '2018-03-22 06:47:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-03-22 07:14:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-03-22 07:14:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

you can also consider not backporting py35 and only run this for master and future stable branches...'}, {'account_id': 13157, 'date': '2018-03-22 07:37:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> you can also consider not backporting py35 and only run this for
 > master and future stable branches...

Yes, the backporting was initiated by the Debian package maintainer, we decided only accept the patches for Queens.

As we only have 3 stable branches, when the queens branch is ready, it may be better to use negative filter to match the ocata and pike branches, and avoid further trivial changes like this. This may be a little annoying, sorry for that.

Thanks for helping on this, :)'}, {'account_id': 24791, 'date': '2018-03-22 08:14:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2018-03-22 11:05:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 13157, 'date': '2018-03-23 03:03:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi, @Andreas, this patch seems not working as expected.

From the py35 job zuul info triggered by changes in master:

http://logs.openstack.org/79/555479/3/check/openstack-tox-py35/6872a46/zuul-info/inventory.yaml

the "branches" filter is inheritted from project-config/zuul.d/projects.yaml.

But for changes in the Queens branch:

http://logs.openstack.org/80/554680/1/check/openstack-tox-py35/7b61736/zuul-info/inventory.yaml

"project-config/zuul.d/projects.yaml" does not appear in the zuul._inheritance_path.

So maybe when Zuul loads job inheritance, the branch of the change is also checked?'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-03-23 07:43:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Zhao Chao, please ask Jim Blair on #openstack-infra during US hours.'}, {'account_id': 13157, 'date': '2018-03-23 07:48:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Zhao Chao, please ask Jim Blair on #openstack-infra during US
 > hours.

Andreas, got that, thanks.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-22 01:21:54.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Use -python35-jobs-horizon for trove-dashboard"

We're going to cherry-pick the py35 related patches to the stable
branches, however this cannot be achieved because py35 gate jobs are
now voting, so temporarily make them non-voting, we'll come back to it
after the patches are merged into the stable branches.

This reverts commit 4704f8be2e2e05a3ede29d9939af71dda907a169.

Change-Id: I3421c945534dc249c42cef9977398ce6c376436e
'}, {'created': '2018-03-22 06:45:51.000000000', 'message': "Temporarily disable py35 jobs for trove-dashboard stable branches

We're going to cherry-pick py35 related patches to the stable branches
first(with the jobs enabled, patches cannot be merged), then we'll
reenable the jobs again.

Change-Id: I3421c945534dc249c42cef9977398ce6c376436e
Signed-off-by: Zhao Chao <zhaochao1984@gmail.com>
"}, {'created': '2018-03-22 06:47:56.000000000', 'message': "Temporarily disable py35 jobs for trove-dashboard stable branches

We're going to cherry-pick py35 related patches to the stable branches
first(with the jobs enabled, patches cannot be merged), then we'll
reenable the jobs again.

Change-Id: I3421c945534dc249c42cef9977398ce6c376436e
Signed-off-by: Zhao Chao <zhaochao1984@gmail.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Temporarily disable py35 jobs for trove-dashboard stable branches

We're going to cherry-pick py35 related patches to the stable branches
first(with the jobs enabled, patches cannot be merged), then we'll
reenable the jobs again.

Change-Id: I3421c945534dc249c42cef9977398ce6c376436e
Signed-off-by: Zhao Chao <zhaochao1984@gmail.com>

[{'created': '2018-03-09 08:14:18.000000000', 'message': 'make glance driver support image:tag

Currently, glance does not support processing tag.
The purpose of the BP is to enable glance_driver to support

commit_message:
make glance driver support image:tag

Currently, glance does not support processing tag.
The purpose of the BP is to enable glance_driver to support
the processing of tag

Support the user to enter a glance image like: image:tag

1/ When the user uploads a docker image to glance,
the image must be named in the way of 'image:tag',
that means, the 'image:tag' is a image name.

2/ When the user uploads docker image to glance,
the image needs to set the tags parameter.
eg. 'glance image-create --tags tag:test --file ubuntu.tar
--name ubuntu --disk-format qcow2 --container-format docker --progress'

Currently implementing the second scheme

Change-Id: Ie44f4605512552d2c204c4b410f1a3bce0f2f3c0
Implements:blueprint glance-support-tag

messages:
[{'account_id': 23517, 'date': '2018-01-17 16:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2018-01-17 16:16:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

This file is autogenerated by sphinx at doc build time:

https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/master/doc/source/conf.py#L56-L60

The config file changes from time to time and the change for a static in repo file to go stale is quite high (we used to package it and it would be out of date every couple of weeks). We switched to autogeneration to solve this so the sample config is always up to date with the version of code you're building the docs with. This is why we put this in the gitignore so no one accidentally commits it:

https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/master/.gitignore"}, {'account_id': 21690, 'date': '2018-03-23 07:39:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 23517, 'date': '2018-03-23 07:39:51.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Update python-ironicclient G-R for rocky cycle

The python-ironicclient library has been updated to 2.3.0
for the rocky release which includes support for the RESCUE
feature. This is required for integration of that feature
via the client library.

Change-Id: Ice6bb1d7669d055cc11aa2e6bb041c0a5164770c

commit_message:
Dell EMC SC: API 4.0 incompatibilities

4.0 folder paths begin with a /. Also add a check that the user formatted
the folder path correctly.

Change-Id: I9bdc17c3f0daab97c33908bf3b96fbce963aa9f2
Closes-Bug: #1719428
(cherry picked from commit d414696c66ebc30c098cbb1ae24e4e772c15aca4)

[{'created': '2018-03-20 18:17:35.000000000', 'message': 'Dell EMC SC: ISCSI initialize_connection fixes.

Driver was not honoring the server in ISCSI and returning connection
information for all servers (IQNs) connected to a volume.

If multiple servers are mapped to a volume the driver was only returning
the first server for a given portal.

Closes-Bug: #1756914
Change-Id: If65780000fa8f59f663b00b88584cf289effa590
(cherry picked from commit 96b77e0aa62790320d16f7229aaeeb650fa875b6)
'}]
commit_message:
Dell EMC SC: ISCSI initialize_connection fixes.

Driver was not honoring the server in ISCSI and returning connection
information for all servers (IQNs) connected to a volume.

If multiple servers are mapped to a volume the driver was only returning
the first server for a given portal.

Closes-Bug: #1756914
Change-Id: If65780000fa8f59f663b00b88584cf289effa590
(cherry picked from commit 96b77e0aa62790320d16f7229aaeeb650fa875b6)

subject: fix mount error in lvm snapshot when filesystem type is XFS
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-23 06:42:57.000000000', 'message': "fix mount error in lvm snapshot when filesystem type is XFS

when lvm filesystem type is XFS,I get the mount error:
Filesystem has duplicate UUID {UUID} - can't mount
I checked the code and find a mistake，fix it.

Change-Id: Ic4dd5709b80d75fbe59875d79cd8a723154e7abd
Closes-Bug:1758252
"}]
commit_message:
fix mount error in lvm snapshot when filesystem type is XFS

when lvm filesystem type is XFS,I get the mount error:
Filesystem has duplicate UUID {UUID} - can't mount
I checked the code and find a mistake，fix it.

Change-Id: Ic4dd5709b80d75fbe59875d79cd8a723154e7abd
Closes-Bug:1758252

messages: [{'account_id': 13157, 'date': '2018-03-19 11:29:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26970, 'date': '2018-03-20 10:14:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 24791, 'date': '2018-03-21 13:55:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 26970, 'date': '2018-03-21 14:17:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 25113, 'date': '2018-03-22 01:04:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2\n\nrecheck'}, {'account_id': 24739, 'date': '2018-03-23 03:51:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-19 11:29:53.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Fix false-negative failure report for mysqldump backup"

The approach merged in I2c10ae7b6b6094af7819594e889385b0ed77fe4b is not
a complete solution, mysqldump will dump warning to stderr too which
should not break the backup process. A better fix would be doing checks
against the stderr logs just like the InnoBackupEx strategy does.

See also: https://bugs.launchpad.net/trove/+bug/1756806

This reverts commit 49fea478ee6d2fe67f6c248b8da9b0ce910184f8.

Change-Id: Ia8f938619de48b7c0d2efd6753897335a8ebce41
'}, {'created': '2018-03-21 14:17:43.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Fix false-negative failure report for mysqldump backup"

The approach merged in I2c10ae7b6b6094af7819594e889385b0ed77fe4b is not
a complete solution, mysqldump will dump warning to stderr too which
should not break the backup process. A better fix would be doing checks
against the stderr logs just like the InnoBackupEx strategy does.

See also: https://bugs.launchpad.net/trove/+bug/1756806

This reverts commit 49fea478ee6d2fe67f6c248b8da9b0ce910184f8.

Change-Id: Ia8f938619de48b7c0d2efd6753897335a8ebce41
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Fix false-negative failure report for mysqldump backup"

The approach merged in I2c10ae7b6b6094af7819594e889385b0ed77fe4b is not
a complete solution, mysqldump will dump warning to stderr too which
should not break the backup process. A better fix would be doing checks
against the stderr logs just like the InnoBackupEx strategy does.

See also: https://bugs.launchpad.net/trove/+bug/1756806

This reverts commit 49fea478ee6d2fe67f6c248b8da9b0ce910184f8.

Change-Id: Ia8f938619de48b7c0d2efd6753897335a8ebce41
